componenttext: And this is what typically the industry standard is, is either 4% to 5% on skilled and 2% to 3% of revenue on hospital assets. So yes, so that would be about, in total, on our Kindred portfolio, about 30 basis points to get from EBITDARM, which is 2x to EBITDAR.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then on the RIDEA, I think Bob mentioned a onetime expense in '14. That kind of maybe messed up the year-over-year comps on the expense side, I believe, correct me if I'm wrong. But if you could give us a sense of what that would have been on a normal
componenttext: And then on the RIDEA, I think Bob mentioned a onetime expense in '14. That kind of maybe messed up the year-over-year comps on the expense side, I believe, correct me if I'm wrong. But if you could give us a sense of what that would have been on a normalized basis? And as a whole, what you guys are expecting sort of for occupancy rate and expense growth for '16 and if you have any sense of how the first quarter is trending to date.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Juan, so I think there are a few questions in there. Let me start with the fourth quarter and characterize the nonrecurring expenses where they hit. They were about $1.7 million. That takes -- when you adjust for those the NOI growth from 1.1% to ab
componenttext: Sure, Juan, so I think there are a few questions in there. Let me start with the fourth quarter and characterize the nonrecurring expenses where they hit. They were about $1.7 million. That takes -- when you adjust for those the NOI growth from 1.1% to about 2.4% same store for the quarter, so pretty much in line quarter and year if you look at it that way. And these nonrecurring tend to normalize over the course of the year, so I think that's a reasonable way to view the year overall. The margin and expense versus revenue profile in the fourth quarter to note reflects that onetime-type benefit in 2014. So when you align for those, the margins are really in line, expense grew in line with revenue. So that's the fourth quarter. As we think about '16 and how we model '16, overall on a blended basis, I highlighted a 1% to 3% outlook for SHOP overall. Really has 2 building blocks to that and really important to highlight those. The first is, we call it, the 70% engine room of growth, the markets like New York, Los Angeles, the coastal markets in which we have a strong hold, we think those markets are going to grow mid single digits. So that's a continuation of the momentum we've seen in those markets in 2015. That will be partially offset by, call it, 30%. That is the list of markets which may be affected by supply challenges. And really, to think about what those challenges might be, it's hard to model exactly because it could be a function of occupancy. It could be a function of rate, even a potential expense impact. But overall, we think that on a blended basis, that performance for that 30% will bring down the overall average, so partially offset the strength and momentum we see in the 70%. Therefore, overall, coming back to your 1% to 3% growth overall, showing the benefit of the great portfolio, which we think we have. So within that, I can give more assumptions, but that's sort of the overall flavor for '16.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that 30% is going to have a mid single-digit negative-type number to offset that 70 -- most of the growth of that 70%. Is that a fair characterization?
componenttext: So that 30% is going to have a mid single-digit negative-type number to offset that 70 -- most of the growth of that 70%. Is that a fair characterization?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think it will be a range. Indeed, we went back to try to truly understand this and modeled where we have assets, where there has been new supply coming on online, what happens. And we've had pretty good experience of call it, 40 properties where we've
componenttext: We think it will be a range. Indeed, we went back to try to truly understand this and modeled where we have assets, where there has been new supply coming on online, what happens. And we've had pretty good experience of call it, 40 properties where we've seen that. And there tends to be a wide dispersion of outcomes there as there will be in any portfolio. But overall, our guidance range reflects what we think sort of the central median is of that. So you can do the math as you did to reflect the overall for that. But again, that's a partial offset to the 70%.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: Sure. Thank you, yes, I should mention that. So I highlighted first of all, strong rent into rental increases effective January 1 mid single digit, which is really great news, we're really pleased to see that. We're really pursuing a rate-driven strategy. We think that's a wonderful way to drive profitability. And seeing those rate letters go out in that performance, thus far holding is very encouraging. That, together with the fact as you note that we have the flu season challenge in the prior year that we're lapping would suggest just from a facing point of view the first quarter would be a better comparable for us overall for the year. So we're pleased with the start. Obviously, the occupancy that we begin the year with is below last year. But again, that's reflective of that rate strategy I highlighted, so very intentional as we think about our first quarter performance.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: Next question comes from Smedes Rose with Citigroup.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you, now that you've had a little more time to see some of the new supply coming into your markets for the -- on the SHOP side of the business, are you seeing, I think, as you've indicated before that maybe the competitors are a little mor
componenttext: I wanted to ask you, now that you've had a little more time to see some of the new supply coming into your markets for the -- on the SHOP side of the business, are you seeing, I think, as you've indicated before that maybe the competitors are a little more aggressive in pricing and is that still how it's playing out as they come along? And are they typically targeting the same price point customer that you guys are? Or is it something below or maybe just some color around how the competitors are behaving?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think it's important to highlight the points you make, which is we've assumed in our methodology that all new supply will compete. We think that's a conservative point of view. Because as you say, price point model AL versus IL, location, operator
componenttext: Sure. I think it's important to highlight the points you make, which is we've assumed in our methodology that all new supply will compete. We think that's a conservative point of view. Because as you say, price point model AL versus IL, location, operator, all matter. We think in a very conservative position we think to assume that there will be some level of competition irrespective of those items. So that's a conservative point of view. Indeed, what we do see though is differing ways that folks compete within the market. As I said, it could be occupancy, it could be rate. The key for us is really to drive the operational excellence, I'll come back to that, that theme, to really win and grow in those markets. So when you have a great team, you have great processes, you can differentiate yourselves. You have a great track record to compete against the shiny new penny, as I describe it, and win. And that's where we're really focused.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I wanted to ask you just sort of bigger picture, I guess, too. I mean the overall acquisition activity has slowed or slowed in the second half of '15, in general, across REITs. What sort of changes are you seeing, if any, on pricing? I mean is there
componenttext: Okay. I wanted to ask you just sort of bigger picture, I guess, too. I mean the overall acquisition activity has slowed or slowed in the second half of '15, in general, across REITs. What sort of changes are you seeing, if any, on pricing? I mean is there kind of a repricing underway that sellers can start moving product more quickly? Or are they kind of holding fast? Or what are you seeing in general?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, this is Debbie. I would say that as we've talked about the last couple of quarters, we've been very selective in terms of our investment activity, very focused in terms of our capital allocation and there definitely has been a period of price disc
componenttext: Smedes, this is Debbie. I would say that as we've talked about the last couple of quarters, we've been very selective in terms of our investment activity, very focused in terms of our capital allocation and there definitely has been a period of price discovery ongoing and volatility certainly creates a wider bid-ask spread. And so until we get through that time period, I think you will see, again very selective investment activity on our part. But we are sort of midway through that process, I would say. And there are deals that we want to do and that we can do. And those again will be development, redevelopment. It will be hospital. It will be supporting our customers with the right kind of assets to help them build market share. And we still think there are opportunities for us to play but very selectively.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we learned something last year, no doubt. As the year progressed, there's a lot we, talked about, whether it's flu season or challenges year on year with any 1 quarter. But certainly, the reality of increasing supply as the year unfolded presented
componenttext: I think we learned something last year, no doubt. As the year progressed, there's a lot we, talked about, whether it's flu season or challenges year on year with any 1 quarter. But certainly, the reality of increasing supply as the year unfolded presented itself. And we saw that, in fact, particularly in the fourth quarter as I highlighted. So as we think about '16, we think we played it down the middle, Andrew. We've looked at the momentum in the current markets, and as I say, we expect that to continue. It's really a question then of modeling what is the supply impact going to be. And only time will tell, but we try to be as factual as we could be, as I said, looking at experience. And therefore, we think we've played it right down the middle, but we'll see.

componenttext: This is John. We're seeing -- we're still seeing both Class A and Class B medical office trade-in in the 6 to 6.5, sometimes below 6. The senior housing side, we haven't really seen any -- a lot of Class A senior housing properties come to market. But we've also seen a fair amount of Class Bs move up 50 basis points in spreads.

componenttext: One interesting data point that we have is Bob mentioned that we did sell some assets in the first quarter. And we sold a senior housing asset in Salt Lake City for a 6 cap and generated a very significant gain on that. So that's one data point that would suggest that the cap rates for senior -- quality senior housing remain pretty strong certainly for good quality assets like we own.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Chad Vanacore from Stifel.
componenttext: Next question comes from Chad Vanacore from Stifel.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bob, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that MOB costs crept up in the fourth quarter. And can you unpack that a little bit and tell us what was driving that?
componenttext: So Bob, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned that MOB costs crept up in the fourth quarter. And can you unpack that a little bit and tell us what was driving that?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Again, I think quarter-to-quarter volatility is a fact of life, not only in SHOP but in MOB. In particular, in the case of fourth quarter, I highlighted we had some unexpected R&M cost increases. There tends to be some variability and volatility in
componenttext: Sure. Again, I think quarter-to-quarter volatility is a fact of life, not only in SHOP but in MOB. In particular, in the case of fourth quarter, I highlighted we had some unexpected R&M cost increases. There tends to be some variability and volatility in those. And we got hit particularly in the fourth quarter and late in the fourth quarter for that matter. So I'd really come back to the full year performance of 2%. That's very much in line with the expectation for '16 , steady and stable as you go would be the way I would highlight that. So kind of a unique quarter just in the fourth.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just thinking about your overall assumptions on your same-store NOI for SHOP portfolio in that 1% to 3% range, can you guys give us a little more detail on how you're thinking about rate versus occupancy in that number?
componenttext: All right. And then just thinking about your overall assumptions on your same-store NOI for SHOP portfolio in that 1% to 3% range, can you guys give us a little more detail on how you're thinking about rate versus occupancy in that number?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On a blended basis, so for the total portfolio, I would say flattish on occupancy. Again, I come back to we're very much pursuing a rate-driven strategy. When you look at NOI sensitivities, rate very much trumps occupancy, and therefore, we think a
componenttext: Sure. On a blended basis, so for the total portfolio, I would say flattish on occupancy. Again, I come back to we're very much pursuing a rate-driven strategy. When you look at NOI sensitivities, rate very much trumps occupancy, and therefore, we think a good profit approach. And therefore, as we look at it, the NOI is driven by rate. And again, very much encouraged by the start to the year. Those rate letters are important. So that mid-single digit rate increase starting Jan 1 really is central to that full year performance.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the Jan 1 rate increases, what percent of your portfolio get those bumps on Jan 1?
componenttext: Okay. And on the Jan 1 rate increases, what percent of your portfolio get those bumps on Jan 1?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: The majority. There is some staggered timing on it. It's not everybody starts on the first of Jan. There'll be from different time periods but the majority.
componenttext: The majority. There is some staggered timing on it. It's not everybody starts on the first of Jan. There'll be from different time periods but the majority.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just thinking about your markets and the 70% of markets that are not facing pressure, would you say most of those are high-barrier markets in terms of rent or any other local functions?
componenttext: All right. And then just thinking about your markets and the 70% of markets that are not facing pressure, would you say most of those are high-barrier markets in terms of rent or any other local functions?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are absolutely the high-barrier markets. At the Investor Day, we talked about the fact, 50% of our SHOP portfolio is in coastal markets And when you look at those, that is where we really see the strength. We see high rates, high RevPOR, we see high
componenttext: They are absolutely the high-barrier markets. At the Investor Day, we talked about the fact, 50% of our SHOP portfolio is in coastal markets And when you look at those, that is where we really see the strength. We see high rates, high RevPOR, we see high margin. And we see very limited supply. In New York, our largest market is the case study of that. I've highlighted the last 2 quarters, the strong performance in NOI, that strong momentum really reflects that great position, great market scale, this idea of cluster markets and very limited supply. And so those together drive that engine of growth, I'd call it, that we've seen in '15 and expect in '16.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Ross Nussbaum from UBS.
componenttext: Next question comes from Ross Nussbaum from UBS.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, can you talk about underlying your commentary that 70-plus percent of your markets are at equilibrium or better status on the senior housing side, you had said that, that assumes 3% absorption. Why do you believe that in 2016, 3% absorption is the
componenttext: Debbie, can you talk about underlying your commentary that 70-plus percent of your markets are at equilibrium or better status on the senior housing side, you had said that, that assumes 3% absorption. Why do you believe that in 2016, 3% absorption is the right number? Or is that longer-term aging of the baby boomer long-term trend assumption?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ross, it's Bob. We've modeled it every which way, I would tell you. That 3% assumption really looks at a 75-plus population and its growth rate in '16 and the CAGR of the next 5 years. If you look at it 80 plus within our trade rings, you kind of come bac
componenttext: Ross, it's Bob. We've modeled it every which way, I would tell you. That 3% assumption really looks at a 75-plus population and its growth rate in '16 and the CAGR of the next 5 years. If you look at it 80 plus within our trade rings, you kind of come back to the same sort of number. That central tendency, I would say, of 30% of the portfolio being exposed really comes back no matter which methodology. The 3%, therefore, is a combination of population growth and then some level of obsolescence, which is relatively small. Overall, averaging assumption, it will differ by market. But we think, as we pressure tested it, we think it holds up very well.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couldn't have said it better myself, Ross.
componenttext: Couldn't have said it better myself, Ross.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. The second question, I'm looking at Page 20 of your supplemental. In October of last year, you guys had a disposition of some triple-net senior housing assets for $78 million 4 48. And then you also had a debt investment of $78 million 4 48. Did you swap in equity stake for a debt investment, or were those the same assets?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are the same assets. And if you look at Brookdale's disclosure, you'll see something similar. Brookdale had some purchase options on NHP assets. And basically, we have helped Brookdale exercise those purchase options as they have basically purchased
componenttext: They are the same assets. And if you look at Brookdale's disclosure, you'll see something similar. Brookdale had some purchase options on NHP assets. And basically, we have helped Brookdale exercise those purchase options as they have basically purchased the assets. And we have provided purchase money financing that is secured and guaranteed with those assets over a 5-year time period.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: That looks like the same yield as what you had when you actually owned the property.
componenttext: That looks like the same yield as what you had when you actually owned the property.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly, exactly. So it's a good collaborative deal for both companies.
componenttext: Exactly, exactly. So it's a good collaborative deal for both companies.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: So when you look at Ardent and you think of the same-store growth profile of that organization within your -- or under your flag now, I understand you don't have a same-store outlook because you don't have the right amount of time with it, but what do you think about that as an internal growth engine? Is it in the low single digits like everything else? Or is it something different?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I think in general, the healthcare services business over long periods of time will generate low single digits same-store EBITDARM growth. We have always structured our leases and our investments in those businesses with a margin of safety thr
componenttext: Yes. I mean I think in general, the healthcare services business over long periods of time will generate low single digits same-store EBITDARM growth. We have always structured our leases and our investments in those businesses with a margin of safety through property cash flows, coverages, credit in structure. And so you'll see ebbs and flows that are predictable and contemplated in those cash flows. But over time they're, as you say, in the low single digits; and if properly structured, will provide good risk-adjusted, reliable rents and rent growth.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: As I mentioned without commenting at all expressly or impliedly on any particular asset, I would tell you that we're actively working with Ardent EGI on acquisition and investment activity. And it's very high-quality market share and numerous other characteristics that we laid out there. So that's what you should focus on as you're looking at where we would be likely to invest with Ardent.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: Next question comes from John Kim from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: In your announcements of new supply pressures on senior housing, what is the rationale of using a 3- and 7-mile radius as a metric?
componenttext: In your announcements of new supply pressures on senior housing, what is the rationale of using a 3- and 7-mile radius as a metric?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Another good question, because there's been a lot of debate around that. It really comes back to looking at where the source of business is and how far folks are typically willing to travel, which for each of the properties, our operators understand that
componenttext: Another good question, because there's been a lot of debate around that. It really comes back to looking at where the source of business is and how far folks are typically willing to travel, which for each of the properties, our operators understand that as they do their marketing. It intuitively makes sense for the highest density areas. You're not going to go very far. You're going to walk. You're going to drive a short distance whereas the more rural or suburban areas, you're going to drive. And so it's really a function of that. John, you can look at it and cut it different ways. Your denominator changes depending on how broad the ring you draw is. So it doesn't necessarily change the numbers overall, but we think it ties back to where the business is coming from.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then we all know in New York, 3 miles is far. And in some other areas, 7 miles would be the equivalent. So that's really how to think about it.
componenttext: And then we all know in New York, 3 miles is far. And in some other areas, 7 miles would be the equivalent. So that's really how to think about it.

componenttext: Okay. And then also moving on to medical office buildings, you expect a lower growth rate in 2016, but higher occupancy in rate growth. So I'm just trying to tie those 2 statements together?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, we have some modest occupancy growth and some modest rate growth. I would highlight that rate growth is not as significant as we saw in 2015, and to some degree, CPI linked. So lower inflation, lower increases. So that really a revenue, and theref
componenttext: So yes, we have some modest occupancy growth and some modest rate growth. I would highlight that rate growth is not as significant as we saw in 2015, and to some degree, CPI linked. So lower inflation, lower increases. So that really a revenue, and therefore, profit mix isn't as rich. And that's really kind of the most fundamental driver of that.

componenttextpreview: The lower CPI, I imagine, impacts all of your triple-net leases?
componenttext: The lower CPI, I imagine, impacts all of your triple-net leases?

componenttext: Yes, the triple-net leases, right. But it landed rightback to the fact, very stable in a great business.

componenttext: Yes, on the triple-net, some are CPI-based and others are contractual-based. And in MOBs, there is a significant CPI component.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then finally on Kindred, now that it's settled with the Department of Justice, can you maybe describe what its relationship is with Medicare?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, I would say the following: Kindred is the leader in postacute care in the United States. As was announced, Kindred settled in a very proactive way with the Department of Justice relative to a claim the Department of Justice made for a company t
componenttext: Okay. Yes, I would say the following: Kindred is the leader in postacute care in the United States. As was announced, Kindred settled in a very proactive way with the Department of Justice relative to a claim the Department of Justice made for a company that Kindred acquired for activities that occurred before the acquisition. Kindred had a reserve of about $125 million for that and has settled that for approximately the amount of the reserve and is in good standing with all programs and has an excellent compliance function, which is one of the many reasons that we like to do business with them and our other providers.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, you touched on another question I had, because Kindred's press release seems to suggest that the claims were mostly regarding rehab care prior to the acquisition. But postacquisition, Kindred has been charging the ultrahigh rate at a very -- ris
componenttext: Actually, you touched on another question I had, because Kindred's press release seems to suggest that the claims were mostly regarding rehab care prior to the acquisition. But postacquisition, Kindred has been charging the ultrahigh rate at a very -- rising in high rate compared to its history. So are they fully settled now with the Department of Justice or can this be an ongoing issue with them?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: They're fully settled with the Department of Justice. Again, the claims are preacquisition of a company called, RehabCare. And Kindred has a very appropriate mix and a high quality mix between the specialty hospitals and the skilled nursing, and we believ
componenttext: They're fully settled with the Department of Justice. Again, the claims are preacquisition of a company called, RehabCare. And Kindred has a very appropriate mix and a high quality mix between the specialty hospitals and the skilled nursing, and we believe consistently, has good compliance and codes appropriately. So I think you may be misunderstanding some data. I'm not...

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Steve Sakwa from Evercore.
componenttext: Next question comes from Steve Sakwa from Evercore.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess first question is for Bob. You've got about $550 million of debt maturing this period at 1.6%. Sort of what are the plans, and what's incorporated into guidance? And any thoughts at also taking a look at the '17 debt maturities?
componenttext: I guess first question is for Bob. You've got about $550 million of debt maturing this period at 1.6%. Sort of what are the plans, and what's incorporated into guidance? And any thoughts at also taking a look at the '17 debt maturities?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Steve. We indeed have $500 million of dispositions factored into the guidance, as I highlighted, and $350 million of new acquisition. So that, together with cash flow, is driving debt reduction. As part of that, we have a rollover, as you hig
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Steve. We indeed have $500 million of dispositions factored into the guidance, as I highlighted, and $350 million of new acquisition. So that, together with cash flow, is driving debt reduction. As part of that, we have a rollover, as you highlighted, some very low cost debt end of the year. Clearly, as we look at interest rates, you're at record lows. We're actively considering different ways to optimize. But ultimately, the key being that we're looking to delever and have highlighted that this guidance brings us below 6x by year end.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess I'm not really clear, what -- are you going to do a bond offering, or it's up in the air at this point?
componenttext: So I guess I'm not really clear, what -- are you going to do a bond offering, or it's up in the air at this point?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll see how things go, but all else equal, we would do a bond to refinance it at the fourth quarter of the year. But if interest rates make it attractive, we may think about doing that earlier, we'll see.
componenttext: Well, we'll see how things go, but all else equal, we would do a bond to refinance it at the fourth quarter of the year. But if interest rates make it attractive, we may think about doing that earlier, we'll see.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. I guess, Debbie, you talked a little bit about the redevelopments and the developments. And that would seem like a better use of capital than maybe straight-up acquisitions. But I'm just curious how you're maybe retooling or reunderwriting d
componenttext: Got it, okay. I guess, Debbie, you talked a little bit about the redevelopments and the developments. And that would seem like a better use of capital than maybe straight-up acquisitions. But I'm just curious how you're maybe retooling or reunderwriting developments today in just light of where the economy is and maybe what changes are you making internally as you assess these projects?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say -- thank you for raising that. We do think that some acquisitions, as we said, and some redevelopments and developments are good capital allocations. On the ground-up development, we are exceedingly selective. And I would point you to the
componenttext: Yes. I would say -- thank you for raising that. We do think that some acquisitions, as we said, and some redevelopments and developments are good capital allocations. On the ground-up development, we are exceedingly selective. And I would point you to the fact that the one medical office building ground-up development that we're doing is expected to be 75% preleased with a AA-rated hospital system; downtown San Francisco, connected to a brand-new hospital. That meets my hurdle for ground-up development. In terms of senior housing development, ground-up, we've got only 2 projects underway, very good market areas in Palm Beach County and San Francisco. And there, where you are looking at different cycles and economies and so on, we are a partial owner and have brought in third-party pension fund capital as a partner to kind of spread the risk and narrow that. We think those projects will be very successful. Atria is going to manage them. They have good developers. But again, the typical Ventas go with opportunities, but also make sure you're managing risks. So those are our 3 ground-up developments. And I think you'll see us continue to be highly selective in those. On redevelopment, we think there are good opportunities. We have been allocating more capital. And those, as we've said, provide good risk-adjusted return.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question, I know the skilled nursing is only about 4%. Can you just remind me why that was retained by Ventas when you did the spin? And are there any plans longer term to take that portfolio to 0 as a percentage of your overall?
componenttext: Okay. And then last question, I know the skilled nursing is only about 4%. Can you just remind me why that was retained by Ventas when you did the spin? And are there any plans longer term to take that portfolio to 0 as a percentage of your overall?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd love to ask you to repeat the question, so let's hear it again. Ventas NOI's 4% skilled nursing. And why did we keep that? Okay. So our strategy is really to, a, maintain a balanced and diversified portfolio. That has always been our strategy. And we
componenttext: I'd love to ask you to repeat the question, so let's hear it again. Ventas NOI's 4% skilled nursing. And why did we keep that? Okay. So our strategy is really to, a, maintain a balanced and diversified portfolio. That has always been our strategy. And we also believe that postacute care is an important component of healthcare delivery in the U.S. We also believe that you're seeing increasing interconnectivity amongst the different segments within healthcare. And so we're seeing, as we showed in our Investor Day, hospitals working with postacute, postacute like Kindred in their home healthcare division, providing solutions to our senior housing operators, et cetera. These are powerful trends that are underway. We have distilled the portfolio in each of those segments, particularly postacute. And with our addition of hospitals to be doing business with the leading providers of care in each of those segments so that we will win with the winners. And that is our strategy, and that is how we've reshaped the portfolio through the spin and the Ardent acquisition. And we have a great company and are in a great spot.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next question comes from Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been answered. Most have been answered here already. But just going back to the debt conversation here, leverage coming down below 6. I was just curious how much of that's just a function of the math? You looked at the acquisitio
componenttext: Most of my questions have been answered. Most have been answered here already. But just going back to the debt conversation here, leverage coming down below 6. I was just curious how much of that's just a function of the math? You looked at the acquisition opportunities and the disposition opportunities. And the math just works out that way versus a more targeted approach to say, "Hey, let's take our leverage down here. Things maybe feel a little bit worse." Just curious how that played out -- macro wise when I say worse.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 12, 2016
componenttextpreview: I absolutely highlighted an important word in the prepared remarks saying that we are deliberately reducing leverage and have said that for the last couple of quarters. We have the benefit of being able to be patient and have been patient. We issued some
componenttext: I absolutely highlighted an important word in the prepared remarks saying that we are deliberately reducing leverage and have said that for the last couple of quarters. We have the benefit of being able to be patient and have been patient. We issued some ATM over the last quarter or so. We're continuing to dispose of assets, $700 million last year, now projecting $500 million in '16. And we have record cash flow. And those things are going to get us under that 6x target. So it's not math, it's very deliberate and it's strategic.
