componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q1 2016 Ventas Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitley, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I will now turn the conference over to your host for today, Ryan Shannon, Investor Relations.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Whitley. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas' conference call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain o
componenttext:
Thanks, Whitley. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas' conference call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain other statements to be made during this conference call may be considered forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. The projections, predictions and statements are based on management's current beliefs, as well as on a number of assumptions concerning future events. The forward-looking statements are subject to many risks, uncertainties and contingencies and stockholders and others should recognize that actual results may differ materially from the company's expectations, whether expressed or implied. We refer you to the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, and the company's other reports filed periodically with the SEC for a discussion of these forward-looking statements and other factors that could affect these forward-looking statements. Many of these factors are beyond the control of the company and its management. The information being provided today is as of this date only, and Ventas expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates or revision to any forward-looking statements to reflect any changes in expectations. 
Please note that quantitative reconciliations between each non-GAAP financial measure referenced on this conference call and its most directly comparable GAAP measure as well as the company's supplemental disclosure schedule are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.ventasreit.com. I will now turn the call over to Debra A. Cafaro, Chairman and CEO of the company.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants. Welcome to the Ventas' First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to discuss large trends fueling our business and report on our stron
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants. Welcome to the Ventas' First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to discuss large trends fueling our business and report on our strong first quarter results from our diverse high-quality portfolio. Following my remarks, Rob Probst will review our first quarter performance and financial results before we welcome your questions. 
On the heels of a productive and value creating 2015, we started our year off strong. Building off our advantage, properties, platforms and people, we extended our long track record of excellence this quarter. We generated normalized FFO per share of $1.04, representing comparable growth of 7% versus the fourth quarter 2015. And we are right on track to deliver our full-year expectation of 3% to 5% comparable normalized FFO per share growth despite projected net asset sales and results since modest deleveraging in the back half of the year. We are well-positioned over the short and long-term to capture opportunities and continue to grow cash flow and value for our investors. Our strong positioning is based on the decisions we made and actions we took in 2015, particularly the CCP spin-off and our acquisition of Ardent, large macro trends that favor our business, our financial strength and flexibility and our well covered dividend with room to grow. Let me address some of these factors. We are excited to do business at the intersection of 2 large and dynamic industries with powerful fundamentals and growth process. Both healthcare and real estate represent nearly 20% of our nation's GDP. Our $1 trillion healthcare real estate market is fragmented and continues to be right for consolidation. We are still in the early stages of asset migration from private to public, given that only 15% of healthcare and senior housing real estate asset is owned by REIT. Overtime, Ventas' excellent, diversified platform should be a magnet for asset growth. Our long-term growth prospects are also supported by the increasing demand for healthcare and senior living products and services created by a large and growing aging population. Longer life expectancy increase the need for health and senior care and seniors have immense spending power and will. Our asset and operators will be the beneficiary of this wave of oncoming demand. 
Turning to the upcoming change to the global industry classification standard, making REIT the stand-alone GIC, we anticipate that this change should attract more capital to our industry overtime. As time pass, we believe our size, leading position in healthcare and senior housing, track record of discipline capital allocation and excellent team make us attractive to generalist investors. Honestly, if I were a generalist investor looking at GDP growth at 0.5% in the first quarter, corporate practice declining for 3 consecutive quarters and global weakness, Ventas looks incredibly attractive. We have a 4.7% dividend yield with room to grow, significant liquidity, a BBB+ balance sheet, diversified business model, high quality asset and impeccable track record of consistent growth in income over cycle, opportunities to grow externally and powerful increasing demand from consumers for our real estate. To my mind, that's a compelling value proposition. So whether there's a new GIC or not, what wouldn't you want to own Ventas? That said, we are obviously, focused on our core REIT investors who are crucial to our continued success and we will continue driving to deliver outstanding results for all of our stakeholders. 
As we look at our company, we also like our positioning with a diversified, balanced and high quality portfolio, generating 83% of our NOI from private pay sources. Our outstanding SHOP assets are located in highly attractive markets with strong home values, medium income and senior population growth. In a MOB portfolio, 88% of our NOI is affiliated with investment-grade hospital and HCA, and 96% of our NOI is on campus or affiliated with leading healthcare systems and hospitals. Finally, Ventas' entire portfolio is advantage with only 4% of our NOI derived from, who our adapting to revolve payment model and upcoming RAC. Ventas enjoys a strong presence across 5 verticals, in each case doing business with the nation's leading providers. This exposure and expertise enables us to invest capital across cycles to create value for investors and customers and fund operator consolidation. Although the vast majority of our NOI is from private pay sources, I do want to note that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services or CMS recently announced its proposals for fiscal year 2017 Medicare reimbursement rate. In general, Medicare rates for different government reimbursed asset classes are slated to increase by varying percentages, subject to previously announced initiative or other offset. We view the proposal as in line with our expectations. On that note, we recently reached positive agreements with Kindred on a long-term acute care or LTAC portfolio to better position it for success. Our agreement contemplates this position of 7 LTAC and retaining full rent under our master leases with Kindred. This is just 1 more example of our long-standing collaborative relationship with Kindred where the companies have repeatedly found innovative ways to create value for both sets of stakeholders. So with our portfolio performing well and liquidity and balance sheet strong, our customers leading our industry and our team aligned and efficient, we are continually looking for ways to create additional value through investment activity that delivers good risk-adjusted return. As we have for the past several quarters, we are being highly selective and picking our spots as we consider investment opportunities. Our focus continues to be on committing capital to high-quality hospitals, funding our selective development and redevelopment projects and helping our customers grow. 
We also have found some intriguing investment opportunities in superior real estate as different layers in the capital, such as our recent investment in a secured junior loan tranche of Blackstone's core life science asset, principally in Cambridge, San Diego and San Francisco. In the acquisitions arena, we see a very deep and active financing investment market for MOB with interest from a variety of investor category. In senior housings too, we see aggressive activity from private equity and pension fund, among others even when communities are in areas with significant construction start. However, the deal size in senior housing has been trending towards the smaller end of the spectrum. In hospitals, our effort continue to gain traction as more providers and their constituents are interested in the benefit that our capital can bring to their organization. Our conversations with hospitals and health systems have been accelerating and broadening. So I have complete confidence in our ole as the leading capital provider in our 5 asset classes and our team's ability to capture opportunities and grow cash flows and value for our investors. However, as you know, the timing and volume of our future investment activities are not subject to precise prediction. 
In closing, for almost 2 decades, we have used the Ventas advantage of superior properties, people and platform to translate the powerful forces of consolidation, demographic demand and dynamism in the large healthcare and senior housing real estate market into consistent growth, income and value creation for our investors. And today, as we stand at the corner of healthcare and real estate, we are well-positioned to continue doing so. Now, to talk about our positive quarter, I'm happy to turn the call over to our CFO, Rob Probst.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. I am pleased to report a strong first quarter for Ventas, which included solid same-store growth, 7% comparable normalized FFO per share growth and an even stronger balance sheet. I'm equally pleased to reaffirm our full-year guidance for
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. I am pleased to report a strong first quarter for Ventas, which included solid same-store growth, 7% comparable normalized FFO per share growth and an even stronger balance sheet. I'm equally pleased to reaffirm our full-year guidance for 2016 of 3% to 5% comparable normalized FFO per share growth. On that note, let me first discuss the performance of our highly productive portfolio of nearly 1,300 diversified healthcare and senior housing properties. Same-store cash NOI growth for the company's total portfolio for the first quarter was 2.9% excluding certain items in their respective 2016 and 2015 period and 1.7 on a reported basis. 
Turning to our first quarter 2016 segment level performance, starting with SHOP. Our SHOP business performed well in Q1. Our reported same-store SHOP portfolio increased 2.9% for the first quarter of 2016 over 2015, which is at the high-end of our 1% to 3% full-year guidance. This reported performance was delivered despite incurring unanticipated real estate tax expenses of $1.2 million in the current quarter relating to prior years. Without these expenses, same-store SHOP NOI growth would have been 3.8%[ph]. Our intentional rate driven strategy as well as the quality of our portfolio was visible in the quarter with same-store RevPAR growth of 4.7% in Q1 2016 versus prior year. The aggressive rate increases had an impact on occupancy that resulted in overall strong revenue growth of nearly 4% in the quarter. Adjusting for the aforementioned property tax charge, operating expenses grew in line with revenue and margins held steady. Consistent with our full-year guidance, our Q1 performance was led by the engines of growth in our high barrier to entry coastal infill locations. Our core markets represent more than 70% of our SHOP portfolio NOI. NOI in these markets increased at a mid-mid-single-digit rate in the first quarter. Within these key markets, New York, Los Angeles and Boston posted particularly strong results the start of the year. We did see the performance impacting Q1 of new units coming online within our relevant trade areas in select markets. As expected, NOI from communities in these markets declined low single-digits in the quarter in aggregate driven by occupancy pressures. Encouragingly, based on the latest NIC data, new construction as a percentage of inventory for our SHOP portfolio declined 10 basis points sequentially to 4.4% in Q1 2016. Our framework by which we evaluate and quantify the NOI impact of new construction in 2016 shared on our last earnings call in February has held up very well this year. We affirm our full-year guidance for SHOP 2016 reported same-store cash NOI to grow in the range of 1% to 3%. From a phasing point of view, the second quarter 2015 generated our strongest NOI delivery last year, enhances our most challenging comparison period in 2016. For the full year, we project continued strong rate growth on lower occupancy levels versus prior year with growth fueled by the continued momentum in our core market. 
Next, I'll cover our triple-net lease asset which account for 44% of our NOI. Triple-net reported same-store cash NOI was roughly flat in Q1 versus prior year. The first quarter 2016 results did not contain $5 million in fee income we've received in the comparable 2015 period. Adjusting for this item, triple-net same-store cash NOI grew 2.9% reflecting customary rent escalations. Cash flow coverage in our overall stabilize triple-net lease portfolio for the fourth quarter of 2015, the latest available quarterly information, was stable at 1.6x. Coverage in our triple-net same-store senior housing portfolio remains strong at 1.3x with solid low single-digit trailing 12 month EBITDARM growth at the asset. Our deliberately constructed portfolio partnered with industry leader, Kindred, now represents only 12% of Ventas' NOI post the CCP spinoff. Our same-store posted cash flow coverage remained a strong 2.0x in Q4 2015. Finally, our Ardent triple-net coverage held steady at 3.0x with solid performance across nearly all key performance indicators continuing into 2016. We are pleased to raise our triple-net full-year reported same-store guidance by 50 basis points to 2.5% to 3.5% growth. Our Q2 and full year cash NOI will benefit by $3.5 million in lease modification fees without loss of rent from the recently announced Kindred LTAC deal that we mentioned earlier. 
Let me close the segment review with our MOB business which represents 23% of Ventas' overall NOI. MOB cash NOI in the 270 properties same-store pool grew 4.2%. First quarter 2016 results benefited from an early lease termination fee with net value of $2.3 million. Adjusted for this item, MOB growth in Q1 was 1%. Q1 revenue grew as a result of a modest rate increase on in place rents, partially offset by lower recovery income and occupancy declines driven by the aforementioned early lease termination. NOI benefited from cost productivity in the first quarter on the heels of a milder winter. We continue to forecast the MOB segment will grow reported full-year, same-store cash NOI in the range of 1% to 2% in 2016. We expect a softer second quarter and then to trend higher in the back half of the year as we fill budgeted vacancy. We remain confident in our valuable MOB business and the leverage platform. 
Turning to Ventas' overall financial results. I'll refer to our results on accountable basis which adjust all prior periods with the effects of the spinoff. First quarter 2016 normalized FFO totaled $1.04 per fully diluted share representing 7% growth on a comparable basis over the first quarter 2015. The strong year-over-year growth was driven by the carryover impact of 2015 investments including Ardent together with new investments in the first and same-store NOI growth. Ventas made approximately $150 million in new investments in the first quarter 2016. In addition, the company funded nearly $40 million from development and redevelopment projects during the quarter. To fully equity fund these new investments, since year end 2015 earnings release in February, Ventas opportunistically issued a total of 1.6 million shares of common stock under our ATM with gross proceeds of approximately $100 million at an average price of $62.30. Year-to-date, Ventas has issued 3.3 million shares of common stock with gross proceeds of approximately $190 million. Ventas also contributed asset disposition program filling 7 properties thus far in 2016 with aggregate sales price approaching $70 million. As a result of these deliberate steps, the company's net debt-to-EBITDA ratio improved sequentially to 6.0x. Now, within our 5x to 6x targeted range. Further, fixed charge coverage is exceptionally strong at 4.6x while debt to total capitalization approximated 34%. 
Finally, we are pleased to affirm our guidance to deliver 2016 normalized FFO per share in the range of $4.07 to $4.15. This range represent the comparable normalized FFO per share growth rate of 3% to 5% over 2015. We also affirm guidance for total company same-store 2016 cash NOI to grow in the range of 1.5% to 3%. Our guidance continues to assume 2016 asset dispositions of approximately $500 million, inclusive of dispositions closed year-to-date. We intend to use the net proceeds to reinvest in approximately $200 million of incremental acquisitions and also to reduce debt. Our guidance therefore, assumes further modest reduction in leverage below the 6.0x net debt EBITDA observed at the end of Q1. With a strong 7% increase in normalized FFO to start 2016, we expect that further leverage reduction, asset sales and refinancing activity over the balance of the year will bring the full-year FFO per share growth to our 3% to 5% guidance range. We have assumed no additional material acquisitions, dispositions or capital activity in our guidance. 
In summary, the entire Ventas team is proud of our strong start to 2016 and confident in our prospects for the remainder of the year. With that, I will ask the operator to please open the call for questions.

componenttext: Yes, there is an element of seasonality but year-over-year, we highlighted that it's really driven by the rate increase. But net-net net, we highlighted 4% revenue growth in the quarter and strong underlying profit as a consequence, we think it's a good move.

componenttext: Just kicking with the SHOP commentary here. componenttext: Yes, I think we pushed right rate appropriately. Again, very intentional and I always talk about the value proposition as we try to replicate the services at home with senior housing, it will be twice as expensive as on average it is within senior housing community. So there is clearly opportunity to drive pricing and the operators have seen that and embrace that in our SHOP portfolio. So that's strategic in my mind. What was the other part of the question?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Well, we said [indiscernible] all else equal, that would be benefit it's certainly true but the world is [indiscernible] there were a lot of things that were going on, so it was helpful but it wasn't something that would drive outside performance and net-net when you step back from the adjustment for tax, we grew nearly 4%. So clearly a strong quarter.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And maybe just a follow-up on the guidance just for disposition proceeds. I think that it was 350 last quarter, 200 this quarter. I think that's just maybe you already spent some of that money but also it seems like the wording did change a little bit. I'm probably parsing this too much but specifically calling debt repayment this time, as opposed to sort of redevelopment and development spent. Anything to read into that?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's -- I'm glad you asked the question because what has not changed if we look full year is $500 million of dispositions and $350 million of acquisitions. That is the same from our last guidance. We expressed the acquisitions in the press rel
componenttext: No, I think it's -- I'm glad you asked the question because what has not changed if we look full year is $500 million of dispositions and $350 million of acquisitions. That is the same from our last guidance. We expressed the acquisitions in the press release as $200 million incremental, which is from here as we did $150 million in the first quarter. So that $350 million it kind of a timing issue on when that money is being spent. The balance is fungible in that we can talk about either redevelopment or we can talk about debt reduction. It's simple to understand that we have approximately $350 million of gross debt reduction inherent in that forecast. If we have $500 million to disposed, $200 million of incremental acquisition, the balance will be debt reduction. So that's the math but redevelopment hasn't changed either.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: And the key point is that we also generate cash flow which is fungible as the stores as well.

componenttext: Right, which is a part of that.

componenttext: Right. Well, first of all, it's important to highlight that, that real estate tax charge, which I identified is, in the reported results through the expense line in the quarter and therefore, you need to adjust that out if you're looking at a more underlying performance and that's in line with revenue, roughly in that 4% range as you highlight. Within that clearly, there have been wage pressures whether of minimum wage or as we have shortages of nurses and everywhere else but that comes right back up to the need to drive our wait in part and parcel.

componenttext: Consistent with the guidance. And so holding margin through rate, covering that expense pressure and at the same time driving cost productivity importantly as part of that through operational excellence is inherent in that pulling that margin for the full year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on the development side, you had quite a big going on a housing front, desirable somewhat dense markets Foster City, Fort Lauderdale, but urban course, are they currently attractive for you just as we've seen some of your competitors move in, in
componenttext: Okay. And on the development side, you had quite a big going on a housing front, desirable somewhat dense markets Foster City, Fort Lauderdale, but urban course, are they currently attractive for you just as we've seen some of your competitors move in, in Manhattan for example? If you could get land, what reservations might you have about developing in a more dense setting like in the Manhattan, Chicago, San Francisco for example?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's nice that we were able to acquire the Atria portfolio when we did which had its largest component, the New York MSA, which has been a great market for us. And as you pointed out, we do have 2 high-quality developments ongoing, both will be oper
componenttext: Well, it's nice that we were able to acquire the Atria portfolio when we did which had its largest component, the New York MSA, which has been a great market for us. And as you pointed out, we do have 2 high-quality developments ongoing, both will be operated by Atria, 1 in Foster City in the San Francisco MSA and 1 in Palm Beach County. Obviously, both attractive areas and we continue to look at development, redevelopment opportunities with Atria and others in all these markets and would feel positive frankly about we've found a good site in any of these markets to do a development that we have confidence in. Our bar on ground-up development however, is very high. So we want to make sure that we're really underwriting it carefully and have confidence in the outcome and that's why we have just kind of the MOB in downtown San Francisco with and these 2 senior housing development in these great areas with Atria ongoing right now.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and Debbie, just talk a little bit about your true dealmaking track record in the past, certainly, been 1 that's very looked fondly upon, has been fantastic. And as you look to them around the situations, you've done so effectively many times in the
componenttext: Okay, and Debbie, just talk a little bit about your true dealmaking track record in the past, certainly, been 1 that's very looked fondly upon, has been fantastic. And as you look to them around the situations, you've done so effectively many times in the past and in the skilled nursing space but today with some dislocation in the markets and maybe sporadically throughout healthcare is too strong but there has been a little bit of more dislocation than in the past. What gets you excited? Where do you see opportunities to apply your turnaround expertise?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Well, thank you for the complement, it didn't always feel it at the time but hopefully in retrospect it is a very good track record of disciplined capital allocation by our team. Look, what gets us excited in Ventas is making money for our stakeholders and that has come and will come in many different forms but that's what get us excited and that's what we're going to be continue to drive for.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just -- when I think of the 3 buckets, triple-net, you have RIDEA and you have post acute, those by which we kind of debate the good and the bad. In RIDEA, we can get into the whole bundling and how it can work itself out from a freight perspective. Sa
componenttext: So just -- when I think of the 3 buckets, triple-net, you have RIDEA and you have post acute, those by which we kind of debate the good and the bad. In RIDEA, we can get into the whole bundling and how it can work itself out from a freight perspective. Same with the post acute but the one thing I want to point out is in kind of isolated, the senior housing triple-net which we have for long time been willing to sit on relatively thin red coverage, I know you have 1.3 on an EBITDARM basis but an EBITDAR might be closer to 1.1. And when you factor in the capital expenditures which are born on the operator, do you get below 1 on average and if so, I mean, what's your comment about that from a long-term perspective as from a REIT standpoint?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well we think we have high-quality diverse portfolio with leading operators in our industry. The Brookfield, the Holidays and so on and the portfolios are well underwritten with credit support and assets [indiscernible] offset are growing EBITDARM. And so
componenttext: Well we think we have high-quality diverse portfolio with leading operators in our industry. The Brookfield, the Holidays and so on and the portfolios are well underwritten with credit support and assets [indiscernible] offset are growing EBITDARM. And so we feel we're at a good level of coverage at market days or above market days and with a reasonable CapEx imputed, we're above the 1.0, to 1.1 so we feel very good about it.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not directing it to you because everyone is kind of at the same boat in senior housing triple net. Do you think there is a day were we have to kind of do a refocus on rent escalators and think more in terms of what -- making sure that escalators aren'
componenttext: I'm not directing it to you because everyone is kind of at the same boat in senior housing triple net. Do you think there is a day were we have to kind of do a refocus on rent escalators and think more in terms of what -- making sure that escalators aren't in excess of the EBITDAR growth of the underlying organization?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I think that's a really good comment because over the years, there's been I think a lot of misperception amongst investors that 1 type of investment chop has risk and 1 called triple net doesn't have risks and so on and so forth. When we do unde
componenttext: Yes, yes. I think that's a really good comment because over the years, there's been I think a lot of misperception amongst investors that 1 type of investment chop has risk and 1 called triple net doesn't have risks and so on and so forth. When we do underwriting of any asset that we are acquiring, the end of the day, those assets have to produce cash flow and so that is what we are focused on always first and foremost and then, along with it and all these areas, is it a leading operator, what's the asset and the management team's position in the marketplace. Can we provide additional structure in the case of triple-net and like guarantees and security deposits and so on? And at the end of the day, we're looking for good assets that are going to perform through good operating partners and that's true regardless of structure. So you make a good point and I think we've done that successfully.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we get an update on the impact on the payment implementation and how significant this change the landscape for demand across the spectrum. Specifically there's been some early evidence of home health potentially gaining market share and I was wonderin
componenttext: Can we get an update on the impact on the payment implementation and how significant this change the landscape for demand across the spectrum. Specifically there's been some early evidence of home health potentially gaining market share and I was wondering you can address that as well.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. I think bundle payments are going to help hospitals, so let's start there. And that was of course when underpinning of our hospital thesis and investment and hospitales control more of these dollars in patients and so far, again, this just
componenttext: Good question. I think bundle payments are going to help hospitals, so let's start there. And that was of course when underpinning of our hospital thesis and investment and hospitales control more of these dollars in patients and so far, again, this just started in the 67 markets on hips and knees in April this year. Kindred has said that as far as the cycle goes, it's going to have minimal impact, they believe and in part, I think they are using this new project to prove out that they are best positioned post acute new provider in the country who can deliver really good post acute care limit readmission and do so for a reasonable cost and that's of course the providers in post acute who are going to drive in the future. But there is -- there can be as part of these trends, some evidence that some patients will go directly from the hospital either into senior living, frankly or to home health and that's a trend that has been going on for some time and will continue. But again, still nursing guys have a role to play in the post acute delivery here and there are plenty of these patients, believe me, plenty of people are having hips and knees replaced and so hopefully there are enough patients for everyone.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The hospitals are managing the process but they're not necessarily the lowest cost setting? So how concerned are you about this and will there some losers and winners in hospital growth?
componenttext: The hospitals are managing the process but they're not necessarily the lowest cost setting? So how concerned are you about this and will there some losers and winners in hospital growth?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that will be winners and drivers and consolidators this ardent And others like HCA but, again they're sort of getting the payment in the bundled payment and they're paying the post acute providers. And so we believe that the hospitals will do
componenttext: Yes, I think that will be winners and drivers and consolidators this ardent And others like HCA but, again they're sort of getting the payment in the bundled payment and they're paying the post acute providers. And so we believe that the hospitals will do well and the post acute providers who can deliver a quality and do so on a low-cost and limit readmissions are going to get more market share.

componenttext: So what I'm assuming is why is it lower? And it's really timing if you look at it. We have a number of things particularly in accounts payable line that in prior years -- if you compare to prior year, we have the Kindred fee and other fees we referred to in the first quarter which benefited cash flow in the first quarter roughly $40 million.

componenttext: Of last year.

componenttext: Of last year to bring it back typically Q1 is an outflow seasonally from a timing point of view in a line, so last year was really more of an anomaly as far as that goes. And the other 1 is really timing around the interest payment on bonds that are flowing through interest payable. So there really timing issues, John, but it's a good catch absolutely. You should see the turnaround at the balance of the year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: We always pay attention to cash flow.

componenttext: The next question comes from line of Jordan Sadler of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I would be accused here of having an active imagination possibly but maybe you can help me understand what's going on with the SHOP portfolio? I guess, same-store occupancy is down 90 basis points and despite a mild flu season but last year was u
componenttext: I guess, I would be accused here of having an active imagination possibly but maybe you can help me understand what's going on with the SHOP portfolio? I guess, same-store occupancy is down 90 basis points and despite a mild flu season but last year was up 60 basis points in what seem to be a more difficult flu season. So what seems to be going on here?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think you should be so focused on flu solely because there's a number of factors. Clearly, that as we've said, all those people is a tailwind. You have a number of factors that are impacting occupancy this quarter. We talked a lot about rates
componenttext: Yes, I don't think you should be so focused on flu solely because there's a number of factors. Clearly, that as we've said, all those people is a tailwind. You have a number of factors that are impacting occupancy this quarter. We talked a lot about rates. Certainly, the rate is intentional and it's driving the majority of that. There is also an impact of the new units coming online and affecting occupancy, as I said in my prepared remarks. So that is coming through that line as well and again, in line with our expectations. So it's really a combination of factors which are really hard to pull out anyone.

componenttext: Well, I would say that obviously, when we look at rents, we're looking at it on an effective rent basis. headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one for me, Bob, you highlighted a drop in senior housing construction earlier. I just wanted to get a sense of what you're hearing from your operating partners, maybe your updated thoughts on the trajectory of new starts at least over the ne
componenttext: Just a quick one for me, Bob, you highlighted a drop in senior housing construction earlier. I just wanted to get a sense of what you're hearing from your operating partners, maybe your updated thoughts on the trajectory of new starts at least over the near-term?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would describe it as a modest sequential decline. We talked about 10 basis points in terms of units under construction. So we're certainly, not doing the touchdown dance yet on that. I think where is it headed from here? A good question, we don't h
componenttext: Yes, I would describe it as a modest sequential decline. We talked about 10 basis points in terms of units under construction. So we're certainly, not doing the touchdown dance yet on that. I think where is it headed from here? A good question, we don't have a lot more information than you do. I think everybody is starting to understand without there's been a lot of talk about supply clearly. If there are lenders and developers and anybody else taking note. We hope it's what's going to happen but only time will tell. We have no evidence to suggest that's true.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tayo Okusanya from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tayo Okusanya from Jefferies.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple from my end. First of all, skilled nursing, you have a very strong portfolio but again it's heavily focused on the natural operators. And I'm just curious what you're seeing no that end just given when we look at your rent coverage, it's been com
componenttext: A couple from my end. First of all, skilled nursing, you have a very strong portfolio but again it's heavily focused on the natural operators. And I'm just curious what you're seeing no that end just given when we look at your rent coverage, it's been coming down about 10 bps for the past 2 or 3 quarters?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so most of the change in coverage is due to the fact that rent went up significantly in the fourth quarter of last year, so we think that's a good thing. You want to have good coverage but you don't want to have excess good coverage. You want to hit
componenttext: Okay, so most of the change in coverage is due to the fact that rent went up significantly in the fourth quarter of last year, so we think that's a good thing. You want to have good coverage but you don't want to have excess good coverage. You want to hit that optimal point and so -- and yes, most of our 4% of skilled nursing is with Kindred. We have some with Genesis as well and, look, I think what you're going to see as we talked about overtime is we have very strong coverage at 2x. You are going to see, I think some continued pressures on the business and we are in a great spot with our partners who have credit and who are leading operators to work through those changes and we deliberately retained this portfolio because we believe in it.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Then the second thing, medical office buildings. I know we've kind of gone through the tenant vacating and the impact for the numbers of the quarter but when I take a look at rent growth for the quarter, still seems like it wasn't mu
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Then the second thing, medical office buildings. I know we've kind of gone through the tenant vacating and the impact for the numbers of the quarter but when I take a look at rent growth for the quarter, still seems like it wasn't much and again, I guess, one thing I always struggle with on the MOB side is think store NOI growth, it seems to be 2% to 3% consistently but yet, everyone is kind of paying these very low cap rate for these assets. So I'm just trying to understand why it continues to make since the babies of a reload top rates kind of industry wide?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good observation, and again, happy that we acquired our MOB portfolio which is very high-quality again in that 2010, 2011 time period. I think what drives people to really like MOB is that they are a low-cost setting. You see the demographics and the
componenttext: Yes, good observation, and again, happy that we acquired our MOB portfolio which is very high-quality again in that 2010, 2011 time period. I think what drives people to really like MOB is that they are a low-cost setting. You see the demographics and the utilization statistics with the baby boomers and again the 10,000 turning 65 every day. You see the Affordable Care Act which is improving. The insured population in many states and then, what you're getting as an investor is you're really getting above even at relatively low cap rates, you're getting above core returns with core like characteristics. Very reliable, consistent  steady, finance able asset and in this global thirst for yield were rethought about why people like realized real estate assets, that is a very attractive value proposition and I think that's why you're seeing all of these new entrants and a lot of interest in this asset class.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, lastly, again, I appreciate you indulging me. Can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing at this point in the U.K. 4 seasons put out some pretty weak results a few days ago but again I know their portfolio is very heavily focused on
componenttext: And then, lastly, again, I appreciate you indulging me. Can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing at this point in the U.K. 4 seasons put out some pretty weak results a few days ago but again I know their portfolio is very heavily focused on getting funding from the local authorities. But overall, what you're kind of seeing on that and/or the private pay end would be helpful?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in the U.K., I think we have a small senior living portfolio and then a very nice public partner inspire who is in the customer business in the triple-net lease and we have triple-net leases frankly at both segments in the U.K. I think what we're se
componenttext: Well, in the U.K., I think we have a small senior living portfolio and then a very nice public partner inspire who is in the customer business in the triple-net lease and we have triple-net leases frankly at both segments in the U.K. I think what we're seeing there in the private pay as well as the more long term care business is that there are changes in rules and regulations that affect staffing and that is in fact putting some pressures on the operators there. Our portfolio has been doing well. It's a small portfolio that we've grown and we like but I think on a larger scale basis for both the government reimbursed and the private pay  there are some trends there that are compressing margins.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Whitley. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas conference call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain ot
componenttext:
Thanks, Whitley. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas conference call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended March 31, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain other statements to be made during this conference call may be considered forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. The projections, predictions and statements are based on management's current beliefs as well as on a number of assumptions concerning a future event. These forward-looking statements are subject to many risks, uncertainties and contingencies, and stockholders and others should recognize that actual results may differ materially from the company's expectations, whether expressed or implied. We refer you to the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, and the company's other reports filed periodically with the SEC for a discussion of these forward-looking statements and other factors that could affect these forward-looking statements. Many of these factors are beyond the control of the company and its management. The information being provided today is as of this date only, and Ventas expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates or revisions to any forward-looking statements to reflect any changes in expectations. 
Please note that quantitative reconciliations between each non-GAAP financial measure referenced on this conference call and its most directly comparable GAAP measure as well as the company's supplemental disclosure schedule are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.ventasreit.com. 
I will now turn the call over to Debra A. Cafaro, Chairman and CEO of the company.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants. Welcome to the Ventas First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to discuss large trends fueling our business and report on our strong
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants. Welcome to the Ventas First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to discuss large trends fueling our business and report on our strong first quarter results from our diverse high-quality portfolio. Following my remarks, Bob Probst will review our segment performance and financial results before we welcome your questions. 
On the heels of a productive and value-creating 2015, we started our year off strong. Building off our advantage, properties, platforms and people, we extended our long track record of excellence this quarter. We generated normalized FFO per share of $1.04, representing comparable growth of 7% versus the fourth quarter 2015. And we are right on track to deliver our full year expectation of 3% to 5% comparable normalized FFO per share growth despite projected net asset sales and results since modest deleveraging in the back half of the year. We are well positioned over the short- and long-term to capture opportunities and continue to grow cash flow and value for our investors. Our strong positioning is based on the decisions we made and actions we took in 2015, particularly the CCP spinoff and our acquisition of Ardent, large macro trends that favor our business, our financial strength and flexibility and our well-covered dividend with room to grow. 
Let me address some of these factors. We are excited to do business at the intersection of 2 large and dynamic industries with powerful fundamentals and growth process. Both health care and real estate represent nearly 20% of our nation's GDP. Our $1 trillion health care real estate market is fragmented and continues to be ripe for consolidation. We are still in the early stages of asset migration from private to public hands, given that only 15% of health care and senior housing real estate assets is owned by REITs. Over time, Ventas' excellent diversified platform should be a magnet for asset flow. Our long-term growth prospects are also supported by the increasing demand for health care and senior living products and services created by a large and growing aging population. Longer life expectancies increased the need for health and senior care, and seniors have immense spending power and wealth. Our assets and operators will be the beneficiary of this wave of oncoming demand. 
Turning to the upcoming change to the global industry classification standard, making REITs a standalone GIC, we anticipate that this change should attract more capital to our industry over time. At Ventas, we believe our size, leading position in health care and senior housing, track record of disciplined capital allocation and excellent team make us attractive to generalist investors. 
Honestly, if I were a generalist investor looking at GDP growth of 0.5% in the first quarter, corporate practice declining for 3 consecutive quarters and global weakness, Ventas looks incredibly attractive. We have a 4.7% dividend yield with room to grow, significant liquidity, a BBB+ balance sheet, diversified business model, high-quality assets, an impeccable track record of consistent growth in income over cycles, opportunities to grow externally and powerful increasing demand from consumers for our real estate, to my mind, that's a compelling value proposition. So whether there's a new GIC or not, why wouldn't you want to own Ventas? That said, we are obviously focused on our core REIT investors who are crucial to our continued success and we will continue driving to deliver outstanding results for all of our stakeholders. 
As we look at our company, we also like our positioning, with a diversified, balanced and high-quality portfolio, generating 83% of our NOI from private pay sources. Our outstanding SHOP assets are located in highly attractive markets, with strong home values, median income and seniors population growth. 
In our MOB portfolio, 88% of our NOI is affiliated with investment-grade hospitals and HCA, and 96% of our NOI is on campus or affiliated with leading health care systems and hospitals. 
Finally, Ventas' entire portfolio is advantaged, with only 4% of our NOI derived from SNF, who are adapting to evolving payment models and upcoming RAC audits. 
Ventas enjoys a strong presence across 5 verticals, in each case, doing business with the nation's leading providers. This exposure and expertise enables us to invest capital across cycles to create value for investors and customers and fund operator consolidation. Although the vast majority of our NOI is from private pay sources, I do want to note that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services or CMS recently announced its proposals for fiscal year 2017 Medicare reimbursement rates. In general, Medicare rates for different government-reimbursed asset classes are slated to increase by varying percentages, subject to previously announced initiatives or other offsets. We view the proposals as in line with our expectations. 
On that note, we recently reached positive agreements with Kindred on our long-term acute care or LTAC portfolio to better position it for success. Our agreement contemplates this position of 7 LTACs and retaining full rent under our master leases with Kindred. This is just one more example of our long-standing collaborative relationship with Kindred, where the companies have repeatedly found innovative ways to create value for both sets of stakeholders. 
So with our portfolio performing well, our liquidity and balance sheet strong, our customers leading their industries and our team aligned and efficient, we are continually looking for ways to create additional value through investment activity that delivers good risk-adjusted return. As we have for the past several quarters, we are being highly selective and picking our spots as we consider investment opportunities. Our focus continues to be on committing capital to high-quality hospitals, funding our selective development and redevelopment projects and helping our customers grow. 
We also have found some intriguing investment opportunities in superior real estate as different layers in the capital stack, such as our recent investment in a secured junior loan tranche of Blackstone's core life science asset, principally in Cambridge, San Diego and San Francisco. In the acquisitions arena, we see a very deep and active financing investment market for MOBs, with interest from a variety of investor categories. In senior housings too, we see aggressive activity from private equity and pension fund, among others, even when communities are in areas with significant construction starts. However, the deal size in senior housing has been trending towards the smaller end of the spectrum. In hospitals, our effort continued to gain traction as more providers and their constituents are interested in the benefits that our capital can bring to their organization. Our conversations with hospitals and health systems have been accelerating and broadening. So I have complete confidence in our role as the leading capital provider in our 5 asset classes and our team's ability to capture opportunities and grow cash flows and value for our investors. However, as you know, the timing and volume of our future investment activities are not subject to precise prediction. 
In closing, for almost 2 decades, we have used the Ventas advantage of superior properties, people and platforms to translate the powerful forces of consolidation, demographic demand and dynamism in the large health care and senior housing real estate market into consistent growth, income and value creation for our investors. And today, as we stand at the corner of health care and real estate, we are well positioned to continue doing so. 
Now to talk about our positive quarter, I'm happy to turn the call over to our CFO, Bob Probst.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. I am pleased to report a strong first quarter for Ventas, which included solid same-store growth, 7% comparable normalized FFO per share growth and an even stronger balance sheet. I'm equally pleased to reaffirm our full year guidance for
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. I am pleased to report a strong first quarter for Ventas, which included solid same-store growth, 7% comparable normalized FFO per share growth and an even stronger balance sheet. I'm equally pleased to reaffirm our full year guidance for 2016 of 3% to 5% comparable normalized FFO per share growth. On that note, let me first discuss the performance of our highly productive portfolio of nearly 1,300 diversified health care and senior housing properties. Same-store cash NOI growth for the company's total portfolio for the first quarter was 2.9%, excluding certain items, in the respective 2016 and 2015 periods and 1.7% on a reported basis. 
Turning to our first quarter 2016 segment level performance, starting with SHOP. Our SHOP business performed well in Q1. Our reported same-store SHOP portfolio increased 2.9% for the first quarter of 2016 over 2015, which is at the high end of our 1% to 3% full year guidance. This reported performance was delivered despite incurring unanticipated real estate tax expenses of $1.2 million in the current quarter relating to prior years. Without these expenses, same-store SHOP NOI growth would have been 3.8%. Our intentional rate-driven strategy as well as the quality of our portfolio was visible in the quarter, with same-store REVPOR growth of 4.7% in Q1 2016 versus prior year. The aggressive rate increases had an impact on occupancy but resulted in overall strong revenue growth of nearly 4% in the quarter. 
Adjusting for the aforementioned property tax charge, operating expenses grew in line with revenue and margins held steady. 
Consistent with our full year guidance, our Q1 performance was led by the engines of growth in our high barrier-to-entry coastal infill locations. Our core markets represent more than 70% of our SHOP portfolio NOI. NOI in these markets increased at a mid-single-digit rate in the first quarter. Within these key markets, New York, Los Angeles and Boston posted particularly strong results at the start of the year. We did see the performance impacting Q1 of new units coming online within our relevant trade areas in select markets. As expected, NOI from communities in these markets declined low single digits in the quarter in aggregate, driven by occupancy pressures. 
Encouragingly, based on the latest NIC data, new construction as a percentage of inventory across our SHOP portfolio declined 10 basis points sequentially to 4.4% in Q1 2016. Our framework by which we evaluate and quantify the NOI impact of new construction in 2016 shared on our last earnings call in February has held up very well this year. We affirm our full year guidance for SHOP 2016 reported same-store cash NOI to grow in the range of 1% to 3%. From a phasing point of view, the second quarter 2015 generated our strongest NOI delivery last year, enhances our most challenging comparison period in 2016. For the full year, we project continued strong rate growth on lower occupancy levels versus prior year, with growth fueled by the continued momentum in our core market. 
Next, I'll cover our triple-net lease assets which account for 44% of our NOI. Triple-net reported same-store cash NOI was roughly flat in Q1 versus prior year. The first quarter 2016 result did not contain $5 million in fee income we received in the comparable 2015 period. Adjusting for this item, triple-net same-store cash NOI grew 2.9%, reflecting customary rent escalations. Cash flow coverage in our overall stabilized triple-net lease portfolio for the fourth quarter of 2015, the latest available quarterly information, was stable at 1.6x. Coverage in our triple-net same-store senior housing portfolio remained strong at 1.3x, with solid low single-digit trailing 12-month EBITDARM growth at the asset. Our deliberately constructed post-acute portfolio, partnered with industry leader, Kindred, now represents only 12% of Ventas' NOI post the CCP spinoff. Our same-store post-acute cash flow coverage remained a strong 2.0x in Q4 2015. 
Finally, our Ardent triple-net coverage held steady at 3.0x, with solid performance across nearly all key performance indicators continuing into 2016. We are pleased to raise our triple-net full year reported same-store guidance by 50 basis points to 2.5% to 3.5% growth. Our Q2 and full year cash NOI will benefit by $3.5 million in lease modification fees without loss of rent from the recently announced Kindred LTAC deal Debbie mentioned earlier. 
Let me close the segment review with our MOB business, which represents 20% of Ventas' overall NOI. MOB cash NOI in the 270-property same-store pool grew 4.2%. First quarter 2016 results benefited from an early lease termination fee, with net value of $2.3 million. Adjusted for this item, MOB growth in Q1 was 1%. Q1 revenue grew as a result of a modest rate increase on in-place rents, partially offset by lower recovery income and occupancy declines driven by the aforementioned early lease termination. NOI benefited from cost productivity in the first quarter, on the heels of a mild winter. We continue to forecast the MOB segment will grow reported full year same-store cash NOI in the range of 1% to 2% in 2016. We expect a softer second quarter and then to trend higher in the back half of the year as we fill budgeted vacancy. We remain confident in our valuable MOB business and the Lillibridge platform. 
Turning to Ventas' overall financial results. I'll refer to our results on a comparable basis which adjust all prior periods with the effects of the spinoff. First quarter 2016 normalized FFO totaled $1.04 per fully diluted share, representing 7% growth on a comparable basis over the first quarter 2015. The strong year-over-year growth was driven by the carryover impact of 2015 investments, including Ardent, together with new investments in the first quarter and same-store NOI growth. Ventas made approximately $150 million in new investments in the first quarter of 2016. In addition, the company funded nearly $40 million of development and redevelopment projects during the quarter. To fully equity fund these new investments, since our year-end 2015 earnings release in February, Ventas opportunistically issued a total of 1.6 million shares of common stock under our ATM for gross proceeds of approximately $100 million, at an average price of $62.30. Year-to-date, Ventas has issued 3.3 million shares of common stock for gross proceeds of approximately $190 million. Ventas also continued its asset disposition program, filling 7 properties thus far in 2016 for an aggregate sales price approaching $70 million. 
As a result of these deliberate steps, the company's net debt-to-EBITDA ratio improved sequentially to 6.0x, now within our 5x to 6x targeted range. Further, fixed charge coverage is exceptionally strong at 4.6x, while debt-to-total-capitalization approximated 34%. 
Finally, we are pleased to affirm our guidance to deliver 2016 normalized FFO per share in the range of $4.07 to $4.15. This range represent the comparable normalized FFO per share growth rate of 3% to 5% over 2015. We also affirm guidance for total company same-store 2016 cash NOI to grow in the range of 1.5% to 3%. Our guidance continues to assume 2016 asset dispositions of approximately $500 million, inclusive of dispositions closed year-to-date. We intend to use the net proceeds to reinvest in approximately $200 million of incremental acquisitions and also to reduce debt. Our guidance therefore assumes further modest reduction in leverage below the 6.0x net debt EBITDA observed at the end of Q1. 
With a strong 7% increase in normalized FFO to start 2016, we expect that further leverage reduction, asset sales and refinancing activity over the balance of the year will bring the full year FFO per share growth to our 3% to 5% guidance range. We have assumed no additional material acquisitions, dispositions or capital activity in our guidance. 
In summary, the entire Ventas team is proud of our strong start to 2016 and confident in our prospects for the remainder of the year. With that, I will ask the operator to please open the call for questions.

componenttext: Hi, Mike, and thanks for the question. The framework you refer to, as this as a reminder is the one that we laid out in February which attempted to quantify the impact of supply, where we talked about 70% of our portfolio which is delivering more better in terms of supply and demand and 30% which potentially has a supply surplus. To answer your question, the first quarter, really, we think proved out that framework very much in line. As I mentioned, the 70% engine grew mid-single-digit to very much in line with our expectation. The 30% did have an impact. It declined at a low single-digit rate, again, very much in line with guidance provided in February. So performing very much as expected, and that is with units coming online. So we are seeing units coming online that began about Q3 of last year and will continue basically through the year as per the NIC data. So very much consistent with what we told you.

componenttext: Yes, thanks for asking. We think our life science investment's a great investment on a standalone basis, great sponsor in Blackstone, and this was the core kind of best of the biomed real estate, this tranche of the financing. So regarding life science, I think we've been very consistent for 5 years in our thoughts which are that it is a good asset class, it's only 5% of the pie, and so under the right circumstances, like we found here, if there's an opportunity to make a really good investment, we'll do so. But it's not a must-have like we articulated about the MOBs back in 2008, 2009, which is almost 40% of the $1 trillion pie.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the RACs audits were recently announced. They're called recovery audit contractors who come in and sort of look at the billings under Medicare. And as you mentioned, that process has occurred over time, with hospitals who our well through that, i
componenttext: Okay. So the RACs audits were recently announced. They're called recovery audit contractors who come in and sort of look at the billings under Medicare. And as you mentioned, that process has occurred over time, with hospitals who our well through that, including in-patient rehab. But it's new to post-acute. And I think that you may see some impact either from operators perhaps more conservatively coding, and you may see some impact as you saw in ERF [ph] some years ago where there have -- there are some objections to billings either past or present and that can have some impact on cash flows or EBITDAR. From our standpoint, we believe that Kindred, who is our principal post-acute partner, is very well-positioned. The services that Kindred provide are clinically mandated and approved, and it has a really good infrastructure too. It is ready because, obviously, it's been in the ERF [ph] business as well that's ready to deal with the RAC audits, so we feel good about that.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about private equity and institutional investors having strong demand for seniors housing. What are your thoughts about potentially selling some of your non-primary senior housing assets which seem to be underperforming? And would you be intere
componenttext: You talked about private equity and institutional investors having strong demand for seniors housing. What are your thoughts about potentially selling some of your non-primary senior housing assets which seem to be underperforming? And would you be interested in that? What type of pricing do you think you might able to get on that?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- well, first of all, we do believe in having a high-quality portfolio and having diversification and balance in that portfolio, and that includes markets, asset types, et cetera. So as we look at our normal capital recycling in terms of disposition,
componenttext: We -- well, first of all, we do believe in having a high-quality portfolio and having diversification and balance in that portfolio, and that includes markets, asset types, et cetera. So as we look at our normal capital recycling in terms of disposition, I think senior housing is one of the areas that we would consider having in that pool, and we've said that, and we're constantly checking the market and constantly reviewing our portfolio for the best candidate for capital recycling.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other question I had was on Holiday Retirement. When you made the investment back in, when was it, 2013, there were some, I think, pretty big initial escalations in the rents, getting close to sort of 4%, 5% for several years. Can
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other question I had was on Holiday Retirement. When you made the investment back in, when was it, 2013, there were some, I think, pretty big initial escalations in the rents, getting close to sort of 4%, 5% for several years. Can you talk about your comfort in being able to still get those escalations? I recognize it's not a gigantic time for you, about 3% of NOI, but still there's been some management turnover at Holiday, there's been declines in coverage as reported, but one of your competitors out there has a portfolio with them. And so what I'm wondering is why -- if we should be confident that you can continue to get that extra straight-line rent benefit in your FFO there?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So yes, we did buy a Holiday portfolio. It's a high-quality one. It was one of the earlier, more curated portfolios that Fortress put out there. We did structure it well and in a way to get 4.5% escalators in the early years, the last one of those is in 2
componenttext: So yes, we did buy a Holiday portfolio. It's a high-quality one. It was one of the earlier, more curated portfolios that Fortress put out there. We did structure it well and in a way to get 4.5% escalators in the early years, the last one of those is in 2016. And we would expect, over time, that portfolio to, a, on the rent side, go back to a more normalized level; and over time, to grow into normalized coverage. So it's -- the new CEO, I think, has some great ideas. I think the portfolio in general and the company at Holiday is -- had a good start to the year, and so we feel fine about our rent and feel good about it.

componenttext: We quoted the net benefit, net of the rent we would have received in the period. I think the lease would have expired prior to the end of this year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then how should we think about changes in your portfolio, pro forma for the changes and in Kindred leases? Like what's going to happen to Kindred rent coverage post the transaction?
componenttext: All right. And then how should we think about changes in your portfolio, pro forma for the changes and in Kindred leases? Like what's going to happen to Kindred rent coverage post the transaction?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, good. So thanks for asking about that because we were trying to count here how many good deals that we and Kindred have done together over the last, however, many years and I think it was 8 or 9. And this most recent one is a good example of ho
componenttext: Yes. Okay, good. So thanks for asking about that because we were trying to count here how many good deals that we and Kindred have done together over the last, however, many years and I think it was 8 or 9. And this most recent one is a good example of how both the companies have elevated and improved their portfolios through, over time, as we have engaged in these transactions. So what we've said is we have strong coverage now, a few times in our post SKU portfolio. When you look forward, we'd cap all the rent, we would expect to exit 7 of those outcasts, and of course, we have changes in reimbursement in the LTAC sector starting to come into play in 2016 in September for Kindred. And so when you look at all that net-net-net, we would expect a temporary 10 to 20 basis point impact on coverage as we work through and then normalizing as we come out of LTAC patient criteria. So actually that affects of a whole series of things, but this single transaction, I think, is a great way for both of us to position that LTAC portfolio to succeed.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Deb, what percentage of NOI do LTACs represent for you? And then how does that change pro forma?
componenttext: And Deb, what percentage of NOI do LTACs represent for you? And then how does that change pro forma?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's about 6, and since the rent is -- we're keeping all the rent, plus we're getting $6.5 million, it stays 6%.
componenttext: It's about 6, and since the rent is -- we're keeping all the rent, plus we're getting $6.5 million, it stays 6%.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just one last question on the SHOP portfolio. It looked like occupancy was down quite a bit, 100 basis points sequentially or so. Is that from the new pressure that you're seeing? Or what's driving that?
componenttext: All right. And then just one last question on the SHOP portfolio. It looked like occupancy was down quite a bit, 100 basis points sequentially or so. Is that from the new pressure that you're seeing? Or what's driving that?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the -- there is an element of seasonality, but year-over-year, we highlighted that it's really driven by the rate increase. So a very intentional desire to drive rate, this is a wonderful business, needs-driven and we believe a real opportunity to co
componenttext: Yes, the -- there is an element of seasonality, but year-over-year, we highlighted that it's really driven by the rate increase. So a very intentional desire to drive rate, this is a wonderful business, needs-driven and we believe a real opportunity to continue to drive rate, recognizing the value proposition of senior housing. So we very intentionally have been putting our foot to the accelerator on that, knowing there would be an occupancy impact. But net-net-net, we highlighted a 4% revenue growth in the quarter and strong underlying profit as a consequence, so we think it's a good move.

componenttext: Yes. Yes.

componenttext: When you look sequentially.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
