componenttext: On SHOP, on the expense side, does your NOI guidance forecast 4% plus or minus increases over the balance of the year? And I was just curious how much of the 4% that we saw, 4.5% this quarter, was related to minimum wage versus executive director retention?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, first of all, it's important to highlight that, that real estate tax charge, which I identified is, is in the reported results through the expense line in the quarter and therefore, you need to adjust that out if you're looking at a more unde
componenttext: Right. Well, first of all, it's important to highlight that, that real estate tax charge, which I identified is, is in the reported results through the expense line in the quarter and therefore, you need to adjust that out if you're looking at a more underlying performance, and that's in line with revenue and roughly in that 4% range as you highlight. Within that, clearly, there have been wage pressures, whether of minimum wage or as we have shortages of nurses or whatever else. But that comes right back to the need to drive our weight in part and parcel.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and it's consistent with the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year.
componenttext: Yes, and it's consistent with the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very consistent with the guidance. And so holding margin through rate, covering that expense pressure, and at the same time driving cost productivity importantly as part of that through operational excellence, is inherent in that -- pulling that margin fo
componenttext: Very consistent with the guidance. And so holding margin through rate, covering that expense pressure, and at the same time driving cost productivity importantly as part of that through operational excellence, is inherent in that -- pulling that margin for the full year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the development side, you've got a -- quite a bit going on in the senior housing front in desirable, in somewhat dense markets, Foster City, Fort Lauderdale. But the densest urban cores, are they currently attractive for you, just as we'
componenttext: Okay. And then on the development side, you've got a -- quite a bit going on in the senior housing front in desirable, in somewhat dense markets, Foster City, Fort Lauderdale. But the densest urban cores, are they currently attractive for you, just as we've seen some of your competitors move in, in Manhattan, for example? If you could get land, what reservations might you have about developing in a more dense setting like a Manhattan, Chicago, San Francisco, for example?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's nice that we were able to acquire the Atria portfolio when we did, which had as its largest component, the New York MSA, which has been a great market for us. And as you point out, we do have 2 high-quality developments ongoing, both will be op
componenttext: Well, it's nice that we were able to acquire the Atria portfolio when we did, which had as its largest component, the New York MSA, which has been a great market for us. And as you point out, we do have 2 high-quality developments ongoing, both will be operated by Atria, one in Foster City, in the San Francisco MSA, and one in Palm Beach County. Obviously, both attractive areas. And we continue to look at development and redevelopment opportunities with Atria and others in all these markets and would feel positive, frankly, about if we found a good site in any of these dense markets to do a development that we had confidence in. Our bar on ground-up development, however, is very high. And so we want to make sure that we're really underwriting it carefully and have confidence in the outcome. And that's why we have just kind of the MOB in Downtown San Francisco, with Sutter, and these 2 senior housing developments in these great areas with Atria ongoing right now.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Debbie, just talking a little bit about your dealmaking track records in the past, certainly, you've been one that's very looked fondly upon, has been fantastic. And as you look to turn around tough situations, you've done so effectively ma
componenttext: Okay. And then Debbie, just talking a little bit about your dealmaking track records in the past, certainly, you've been one that's very looked fondly upon, has been fantastic. And as you look to turn around tough situations, you've done so effectively many times in the past and in the skilled nursing space. But today, with some dislocation in the markets and then maybe sporadically throughout health care is too strong, but there has been a little bit more dislocation than in the past, what gets you excited, or where do you see opportunities to apply your turnaround expertise?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thank you for the compliment. It didn't always feel like it at the time, but hopefully, in retrospect, it is a very good track record of disciplined capital allocation by our team. Look, I mean, what gets us excited at Ventas is making money fo
componenttext: Yes. Well, thank you for the compliment. It didn't always feel like it at the time, but hopefully, in retrospect, it is a very good track record of disciplined capital allocation by our team. Look, I mean, what gets us excited at Ventas is making money for our stakeholders. And that has come and will come in many different forms, but that's what gets us excited and that's what we are going to continue to drive toward.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rich Anderson with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just -- when I think about the 3 buckets, you have triple-net, you have RIDEA and you have post-acute, those by which we kind of debate the good and the bad. In RIDEA, we can get into the whole bundling and all and how that's going to work itself out f
componenttext: So just -- when I think about the 3 buckets, you have triple-net, you have RIDEA and you have post-acute, those by which we kind of debate the good and the bad. In RIDEA, we can get into the whole bundling and all and how that's going to work itself out from a REIT perspective, and same with post-acute. But the one thing I want to point out is, and kind of isolated, the senior housing triple-net, which we have, for a long time, been willing to sit on relatively thin rent coverage. I know you have 1.3x on an EBITDARM basis, but on EBITDAR, it might be closer to 1.1x. And then when you factor in the capital expenditures, which are borne on the operator, do you get below 1 on average? And if so, I mean, what's your comment about that from a long-term perspective as from a REIT standpoint?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we have a high-quality diverse portfolio with leading operators in our industry, the Brookfield, the Holidays and so on. And the portfolios are well underwritten with credit support, and the assets, as Bob said, are growing EBITDARM. And so
componenttext: Well, we think we have a high-quality diverse portfolio with leading operators in our industry, the Brookfield, the Holidays and so on. And the portfolios are well underwritten with credit support, and the assets, as Bob said, are growing EBITDARM. And so we feel we're at a good level of coverage at market phase or above market phase, and with a reasonable CapEx imputed, we're above the 1.0x, probably closer to 1.1x and so we feel good about it.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: But -- and you're not -- I'm not directing this to you because everyone is kind of in the same boat in senior housing triple-net. I mean, do you think that there is a day where we'll have to kind of do a refocus on rent escalators and think more in terms
componenttext: But -- and you're not -- I'm not directing this to you because everyone is kind of in the same boat in senior housing triple-net. I mean, do you think that there is a day where we'll have to kind of do a refocus on rent escalators and think more in terms of what the -- making sure those escalators aren't in excess of the EBITDAR growth of the underlying organization?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I think that's a really good comment because over the years, there's been, I think, a lot of misperception amongst investors that one type of investment, called SHOP, is -- has risk and one called triple-net doesn't have risk and so on and so fo
componenttext: Yes, yes. I think that's a really good comment because over the years, there's been, I think, a lot of misperception amongst investors that one type of investment, called SHOP, is -- has risk and one called triple-net doesn't have risk and so on and so forth. When we do underwriting of any asset that we're acquiring, at the end of the day, those assets have to produce cash flow. And so that is what we are focused on always, first and foremost. And then along with it, in all these areas, is it a leading operator, what's the asset and the management team's position in the marketplace, can we provide additional structural support in the case of triple-net in like guarantees and security deposits and so on?  And -- but at the end of the day, we are looking for good assets that are going to perform through good operating partners, and that's true regardless of structure. So you make a good point, and I think we've done that successfully.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, can we get your updated views on the impact of funnel payment implementation and how significant this changed the landscape for demand across the spectrum?  Specifically, there's been some early evidence of home health potentially gaining market s
componenttext: Debbie, can we get your updated views on the impact of funnel payment implementation and how significant this changed the landscape for demand across the spectrum?  Specifically, there's been some early evidence of home health potentially gaining market share, and I was wondering if you could address that as well.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. Look, I think bundled payments are going to help hospitals, let's start there. And that was, of course, one underpinning of our hospital thesis and investment as hospitals control more of these dollars and patients. And so far, again,
componenttext: Yes. Good question. Look, I think bundled payments are going to help hospitals, let's start there. And that was, of course, one underpinning of our hospital thesis and investment as hospitals control more of these dollars and patients. And so far, again, these just started in the 67 markets on hips and knees in April of this year. Kindred has said that as far as this project goes, it would -- it's going to have minimal impact, they believe, and in part, I think they are using this new project to prove out that they are the best-positioned post-acute provider in the country who can deliver really good post-acute care, limit readmissions and do so for a reasonable cost. And that's, of course, the providers in post-acute who are going to thrive in the future. So -- but there is an -- there can be, as part of these trends, some evidence that some patients will go directly from the hospital either to senior living, frankly, or to home health. And that's a trend that has been going on for some time and will continue. But again, the skilled nursing guys have a role to play in the post-acute delivery care. And there are plenty of these patients, believe me, plenty of people are having hips and knees replaced, and so hopefully, there are enough patients for everyone.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The hospitals are managing the process but they're not necessarily the lowest cost setting. So how concerned are you about this? And will there be some losers and winners in the hospital world?
componenttext: The hospitals are managing the process but they're not necessarily the lowest cost setting. So how concerned are you about this? And will there be some losers and winners in the hospital world?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think there will be winners and thrivers and consolidators like Ardent and others like HCA, but again, they're sort of getting the payment in the bundled payment and they're paying the post-acute providers. And so we believe that the hospit
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think there will be winners and thrivers and consolidators like Ardent and others like HCA, but again, they're sort of getting the payment in the bundled payment and they're paying the post-acute providers. And so we believe that the hospitals will do well and the post-acute providers who can deliver quality and do so at a low cost and limit readmissions are going to get more market share.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a question for Bob, on your cash flow statement. Free cash flow from operations historically has mirrored normalized FFO, but this quarter  fell well short of that. From what I can see, this is...
componenttext: Okay. And a question for Bob, on your cash flow statement. Free cash flow from operations historically has mirrored normalized FFO, but this quarter  fell well short of that. From what I can see, this is...

componenttext: I am so -- thank you for asking that because that's something we talked about and we're happy to answer.

componenttext: What I'm assuming is why is it lower? And it's really timing, if you look at it. We had a number of things, particularly in the accounts payable line, that in prior years -- if you compare to prior year, we had the Kindred fee and other fees we've referred to in the first quarter, which benefited cash flow in the first quarter of roughly $40 million.

componenttext: Of last year.

componenttext: Of last year, to bring it back. Typically Q1 is an outflow but seasonally from a timing point of view in a payable line. So last year, it was really more an anomaly as far as that goes. And the other one is really timing around interest payment on bonds that are flowing through interest payable. So they're really timing issues, John, but it's a good catch absolutely. So you should see that turn around through the balance of the year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jordan Sadler of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I might be accused here of having an active imagination possibly, but maybe you can help me understand what's going on with the SHOP portfolio? I guess, same-store occupancy is down 90 basis points, right, and despite a mild flu season. But last y
componenttext: I guess I might be accused here of having an active imagination possibly, but maybe you can help me understand what's going on with the SHOP portfolio? I guess, same-store occupancy is down 90 basis points, right, and despite a mild flu season. But last year, it was up 60 basis points in what seemed to be a more difficult flu season. So I'm just -- what seems to be going on here?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think you should be so focused on flu solely, right, because there's a number of factors. Clearly, that, as we have said, all else equal, is the tailwind. You have a number of factors that are impacting occupancy this quarter. We talked a lot
componenttext: Yes, I don't think you should be so focused on flu solely, right, because there's a number of factors. Clearly, that, as we have said, all else equal, is the tailwind. You have a number of factors that are impacting occupancy this quarter. We talked a lot about rates. Certainly, the rate is intentional and it's the driving the majority of that. There is also an impact of the new units coming online and affecting occupancy, as I said in my prepared remarks. So that is coming through that line as well and again, in line with our expectations. So it's really a combination of factors, where it's really hard to pull out anyone.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of free rent, just in the senior housing world, are you or any of your triple-net tenants currently offering free rent upfront as an inducement? Is that changing at all?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of free rent, just in the senior housing world, are you or any of your triple-net tenants currently offering free rent upfront as an inducement? Is that changing at all?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that, obviously, when we look at rents, we're looking at it on an effective rent basis. There are targeted markets. For example, Brookdale has talked about it, where they're providing concessions in some cases that they used after the Me
componenttext: Well, I would say that, obviously, when we look at rents, we're looking at it on an effective rent basis. There are targeted markets. For example, Brookdale has talked about it, where they're providing concessions in some cases that they used after the Meredith merger, and a lot of those, Brookdale has said, are where they expected burn-offs and not be replaced during 2016. So that would be one example.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And are you guys using concessions as well or that you're not seeing the same thing per se?
componenttext: Okay. And are you guys using concessions as well or that you're not seeing the same thing per se?

componenttext: No, we're driving rate.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quite the contrary, we're going the other way. As I said, we're driving rate, not discounting. And the NIC data would suggest, in terms of rate growth, that similarly across the industry, there's good rate growth. So hopefully, others are seeing the same
componenttext: Quite the contrary, we're going the other way. As I said, we're driving rate, not discounting. And the NIC data would suggest, in terms of rate growth, that similarly across the industry, there's good rate growth. So hopefully, others are seeing the same which is a great value proposition in senior housing.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one for me. Bob, you highlighted the drop in new senior housing construction earlier. I just want to get a sense of your -- what you're hearing from your operating partners, maybe your updated thoughts on the trajectory of new starts at least
componenttext: Just a quick one for me. Bob, you highlighted the drop in new senior housing construction earlier. I just want to get a sense of your -- what you're hearing from your operating partners, maybe your updated thoughts on the trajectory of new starts at least over the near-term?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I would describe it as a modest sequential decline. We talked about 10 basis points in terms of units under construction. So we're certainly not doing the touchdown dance yet on that. I think where is it headed from here? A good question, we don't
componenttext: Right. I would describe it as a modest sequential decline. We talked about 10 basis points in terms of units under construction. So we're certainly not doing the touchdown dance yet on that. I think where is it headed from here? A good question, we don't have a lot more information than you do. I think everybody is starting to understand what's out there. There's been a lot of talk about supply, clearly. And so lenders and developers and everybody else taking note, we hope is what's going to happen, but only time will tell. We have no evidence to suggest that's true.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Tayo Okusanya of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Tayo Okusanya of Jefferies.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple from my end. First of all, skilled nursing, again, you have a very strong portfolio, but again, it's heavily focused on the national operators. And I'm just curious what you're seeing on that end, just given when we look at your rent coverage, it
componenttext: A couple from my end. First of all, skilled nursing, again, you have a very strong portfolio, but again, it's heavily focused on the national operators. And I'm just curious what you're seeing on that end, just given when we look at your rent coverage, it's been coming down about 10 bps for the past 2 or 3 quarters.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So most of the change in coverage is due to the fact that rent went up significantly in the fourth quarter of last year, so we think that's a good thing. You want to have good coverage but you don't want to have excess good coverage. You want to hit
componenttext: Okay. So most of the change in coverage is due to the fact that rent went up significantly in the fourth quarter of last year, so we think that's a good thing. You want to have good coverage but you don't want to have excess good coverage. You want to hit that optimal point and so -- and yes, most of our 4% of skilled nursing is with Kindred. We have some with Genesis as well. And look, I think what you're going to see, as we've talked about over time, is we have very strong coverage at 2x. You are going to see, I think, some continued pressures on the SNF business. And we are in a great spot with our partners who have credit and who are leading the operators to work through those changes, and we deliberately retained this portfolio because we believe in it.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Then the second thing. Medical office buildings, I know we'd kind of gone through the tenant vacating and the impact on numbers for the quarter. But when I take a look at rent growth for the quarter, it still seemed like it wasn't mu
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Then the second thing. Medical office buildings, I know we'd kind of gone through the tenant vacating and the impact on numbers for the quarter. But when I take a look at rent growth for the quarter, it still seemed like it wasn't much. And again, I guess, the one thing I was struggling with on the MOB side is same-store NOI growth, it tends to be 2%, 3% consistently, but yet, everyone is kind of paying this very low cap rate for these assets. So I'm just trying to understand why it continues to make sense to pay this very low cap rate kind of industry-wide.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good observation. And again, happy that we acquired our MOB portfolio, which is very high-quality, again in that 2010, 2011 time period. I think what drives people to really like MOBs is that they are a low-cost setting. You see the demographics and
componenttext: Yes, good observation. And again, happy that we acquired our MOB portfolio, which is very high-quality, again in that 2010, 2011 time period. I think what drives people to really like MOBs is that they are a low-cost setting. You see the demographics and the utilization statistics with the baby-boomers and again, the 10,000 turning 65 everyday. You see the Affordable Care Act, which is improving the insured population in many states. And then what you're getting as an investor is you're really getting above, even at relatively low cap rates, you're getting above core returns with core-like characteristics. Very reliable, consistent, steady, financeable asset, and in this global thirst for yield, where we talked about why people like U.S. real estate assets, that is a very attractive value proposition. And I think that's why you're seeing all these new entrants and a lot of interest in this asset class.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then lastly, again, I appreciate you indulging me. Can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing at this point in the U.K. Four Seasons put out some pretty weak results a few days ago, but again, I know their portfolio
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then lastly, again, I appreciate you indulging me. Can you just talk a little bit about what you're seeing at this point in the U.K. Four Seasons put out some pretty weak results a few days ago, but again, I know their portfolio is very heavily focused on getting funding from the local authorities. But overall, what are you kind of seeing, whether on that end or on the private pay end, would be helpful?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, in the U.K., I think what -- we have a small senior living portfolio and then a very nice public partner in Spire, who's in the hospital business for rehab and triple-net lease. And we have triple-net leases, frankly, on both segments in the U.
componenttext: Yes. Well, in the U.K., I think what -- we have a small senior living portfolio and then a very nice public partner in Spire, who's in the hospital business for rehab and triple-net lease. And we have triple-net leases, frankly, on both segments in the U.K. I think what we're seeing there in the private pay as well as the more long-term care business is that there are changes in rules and regulations that affect staffing and that is, in fact, putting some pressures on the operators there. Our portfolio has been doing well. It's a small portfolio that we've grown and we like, but I think on a larger scale basis, for both the government-reimbursed and the private pay, there are some trends there that are compressing margin.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, thank you very much. I will thank all my colleagues at Ventas for contributing to delivering great results. And I thank all of you for your interest in our company and your support of our company, which we appreciate greatly. And we look forwar
componenttext: Yes. Well, thank you very much. I will thank all my colleagues at Ventas for contributing to delivering great results. And I thank all of you for your interest in our company and your support of our company, which we appreciate greatly. And we look forward to seeing everybody at NAREIT in June. Thank you.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q2 2016 Ventas Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Ryan Shannon, Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christelle. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas' Conference Call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended June 30, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain
componenttext:
Thanks, Christelle. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas' Conference Call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended June 30, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain other statements to be made during this conference call may be considered forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These projections, predictions and statements are based on management's current beliefs as well as on a number of assumptions concerning future events. These forward-looking statements are subject to many risks, uncertainties and contingencies, and stockholders and others should recognize that actual results may differ materially from the company's expectations, whether express or implied. We refer you to the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, and the company's other reports filed periodically with the SEC, for a discussion of these forward-looking statements and other factors that could affect these forward-looking statements. Many of these factors are beyond the control of the company and its management. The information being provided today is as of this date only, and Ventas expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates or revisions to any forward-looking statements to reflect any changes in expectations. 
Please note that quantitative reconciliations between each non-GAAP financial measure referenced on this conference call and its most directly comparable GAAP measure, as well as the company's supplemental disclosure schedule, are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.ventasreit.com. 
I will now turn the call over to Debra A. Cafaro, Chairman and CEO of the company.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants, and welcome to the Ventas Second Quarter Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to report on our strong results from our diverse high-quality port
componenttext:
Thank you, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants, and welcome to the Ventas Second Quarter Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to report on our strong results from our diverse high-quality portfolio, discuss our pending investment in life sciences and medical real estate and provide color on macro trends. Following my remarks, our CFO, Bob Probst, will review our segment performance and financial results and walk through our full year guidance before we welcome your questions. 
We have great momentum at Ventas. [indiscernible our superior properties, platforms and people, we extended our long track record of excellence this quarter. If you invest in Ventas for reliable growth and income on a strong balance sheet, then this is a good quarter for you. 
Leading with results, we delivered $1.04 in normalized FFO per share, representing 7% year-over-year comparable growth. And we remain on track for 3% to 5% normalized FFO growth this year. We were opportunistic in access to debt and equity capital markets, again demonstrating our commitments to financial strength and flexibility, as well as our expertise in capital markets activity. 
As you know, we love cash flow, because it enables us to reinvest in our business and pay you a dividend. Our strong and secure dividend yield of nearly 4% is very attractive and has plenty of room to continue to grow. 
Our strong performance is fueled by our market position as the exciting intersection of health care and real estate to large and dynamic industries with powerful fundamentals and growth prospects. Within this attractive space, our incredible team has made strategic decisions and executed our strategy with sustained excellence. As a result, we have differentiated our portfolio and our company, benefited our shareholders and shaped Ventas for continued success. 
Recent examples of our disciplined capital allocation moves include our successful spin-off of most of our skilled nursing business and our entry into the large growing hospital space with Ardent, both completed last year. The elevation and evolution of our business continued this year with our recent deal to announce to acquire $1.5 billion in high-quality life science and medical real estate operated by best-in-class developer, Wexford. We believe the Wexford deal is both financially and strategically attractive. With the going in cash yield on stabilized assets of 6.8%, it is our wonderful fit with our goal of delivering reliable growth and income through cycles. This investment represents an accretive institutional quality entry into the large and growing health care-driven research and development space. It adds an adjacent business line that further diversifies our portfolio and cash flows and adds a large component of private pay NOI to our business mix. The powerful combination of attractive properties, superior platforms and outstanding people creates the Ventas Advantage. All 3 are on display with the Wexford deal. 
The 25 Wexford properties we will acquire our new, Class A assets that are environmentally advanced and architecturally appealing. I hope you'll go to our website for a property tour to see this portfolio. The assets are also well leased to highly rated top-tier universities, academic medical centers and research companies, including Yale, U Penn Medicine, Wash U, Duke and Wake Forest. Like other areas of our business, our prospective tenants are market leaders. The universities in our portfolio account for fully 10% of all university life sciences research and development spending in the U.S., that's an outstanding way to enter a new space. It was really fun to travel up and down the East Coast with Ryan recently, visiting these hotbeds of academic and commercial research, cutting-edge medical activity, innovation and education. 
The Wexford acquisition also creates another superior platform for Ventas growth. The Wexford team has a terrific reputation within the sophisticated tight knit community of elite universities. Demand is increasing as universities take difficult decisions about capital allocation. In this environment, combining Ventas' capital with a trusted developer who can deliver complex projects that benefit leading institutions should be a winning formula. 
We have an exclusive pipeline for growth with Wexford, with 2 assets under development coming online in 2017 and 9 development sites available to satisfy growing demand in research hubs anchored by leading universities. We already have identified 1 potential new development project adjacent to U Penn Medical, which could get green lighted soon. We're hopeful we can grow the business like we have with Lillibridge and Atria. 
The Ventas people and culture were once again truly exceptional in the Wexford deal. We have always admired the Wexford business and have worked on it many times in the past. So when we were recently presented with the opportunity to acquire it, we were a knowledgeable buyer, with an incredibly fast, sophisticated and interdisciplinary team. With our deep knowledge of the business and assets, substantial trust among the players, a good structure and accommodative capital market, we were able to execute with excellence. If luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity, then Ventas is lucky indeed. Hats off to the team. And thanks to the many Ventas investors who participated in our Wexford equity funding in July. We sincerely appreciate your support. 
Next, I'd like to comment briefly on the investment market. We are remaining highly selective as we consider investment opportunities in the current market. Our cost of capital has improved significantly, but we will only execute on deals we believe will generate reliable earnings growth at an appropriate risk-adjusted return. Thus, our focus continues to be on committing capital to high-quality hospitals, helping our customers grow and funding selective development and redevelopment projects. With the addition of Wexford, we expect our capital allocation to preleased university-based development projects to represent a larger percentage of our investment pie. We believe strongly in our ability to invest capital across cycles to create value for our investors and customers. This confidence flows from the combination of our advantaged position within 5 and soon to be 6 asset classes, our relationships with market leading customers and platforms and our team hard-earned experience and skill. 
Before closing, it's worthwhile to spend a few minutes on the macro environment. In the health care arena, we see an acceleration of the transition to value-based payment model. Just this week, CMS announced that it will layer on additional mandatory bundling for cardiac care in 2017. This and other development support our thesis that hospitals are beginning to exert even more influence in post-acute patient care and cost, and that revenue streams for skilled nursing providers will likely remain under pressure in the near term. In the longer term, diversified post-acute care providers like Kindred, who can deliver quality care in a variety of settings, maintain a sound capital structure and adequate liquidity, and enjoy the benefits of scale should have a competitive advantage. 
From an economic and market standpoint, we are benefiting from multiple tailwinds that favor our business, including domestic GDP growth that continues to hover in the low single-digits, a global thirst for yield, the creation of a new REIT global industry classification and historically low long-term borrowing rates. In this environment, U.S. real estate and Ventas should thrive. With our need-based demographically-driven business model, a superb track record of consistent, reliable growth, external investment opportunities, a best-in-class credit profile, a differentiated business mix that is 84% private pay and a secure, nearly 4% dividend, Ventas should continue to be a magnet for investment dollars. 
Now, to talk about our positive quarter, I'm happy to turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Debbie. I'm pleased to report solid earnings growth on an even stronger balance sheet in the second quarter. Let me jump right into the performance of our high-quality health care and senior housing properties, which, together, delivered same-st
componenttext:
Thank you Debbie. I'm pleased to report solid earnings growth on an even stronger balance sheet in the second quarter. Let me jump right into the performance of our high-quality health care and senior housing properties, which, together, delivered same-store cash NOI growth of 3.5% for the nearly 1,200 assets in the company's quarterly same-store total portfolio. Performance in the quarter was led by our triple-net lease business, which accounts for 43% of our NOI. Triple net reported same-store cash NOI growth was 6.2% in Q2 versus the prior year. Growth in the quarter benefited from a $3.5 million cash fee associated with the previously announced collaborative agreements between Ventas and Kindred. Excluding the Kindred fee, triple net same-store cash NOI grew 4.1% in the quarter, principally reflecting strong in-place lease escalations. Cash flow coverage in our overall stabilized triple net lease portfolio for the first quarter of 2016, the latest available quarterly information, improved 10 basis points sequentially to 1.7x. This strong coverage level reflects the quality of our triple net lease properties and of our operators. Coverage in our triple net same-store senior housing portfolio remained stable at 1.3x. Coverage trends were supported by low-single-digit EBITDARM growth at the asset level for the trailing 12 months. 
Our decision to spin off the majority of our post-acute portfolio in 2015 continues to be validated. Our remaining post-acute portfolio, where SNFs now represent only 4% of our NOI, demonstrated market leading same-store cash flow coverage at 2x in Q1 of 2016. 
Finally, Ardent triple net coverage held steady at 3x, and continues to perform well at the assets. Ardent showed positive momentum in top and bottom line key performance indicators in both the first and second quarters. With the strong first half of the year and the majority of lease escalations now in place for 2016, we are pleased to update our forecast for the triple net segment to grow reported full year same-store NOI in the range of 3.5% to 4%, an increase of 75 basis points at the midpoint. 
We are happy to report another solid quarter in our SHOP portfolio, generating Q2 same-store cash NOI growth of 2.1% versus the prior year. This result is right in line with our expectations and reflects our most challenging year-over-year comparison period in 2015. The framework by which we established our SHOP guidance range for the year is holding up very well in both the second quarter and the first half of the year. And with the first half now under our belt, we have performed at the higher end of our guidance range, with H1 growth of 2.5% versus prior year on a reported basis. 
In the second quarter, as expected, our rate-driven strategy continued to fuel our earnings with REVPOR growth of nearly 4%. Our high barrier to entry infill coastal markets continued to be the engine room of our overall SHOP portfolio growth in the second quarter. These communities, which represent approximately 70% of our SHOP NOI, grew Q2 same-store NOI mid-single digits on continued strong rate growth. Major coastal markets, including New York, LA and Boston, continued to drive consistently outstanding growth in both rates and NOI in the quarter and the first half. In select markets, we observed the impact of new construction coming online within our relevant trade areas. In these communities, same-store NOI posted low single-digit declines in aggregate, driven by occupancy and wage pressures. Again, this performance is consistent with our framework with the approximately 30% of our SHOP portfolio located in markets with the new construction surplus. 
Construction as a percentage of inventory in our trade areas, as reported by NIC, increased in the quarter by 40 basis points to 4.8%. Importantly, however, the amount of our SHOP NOI that is affected by new supply remains at roughly 30%. We have observed that a significant number of projected openings, as reported by NIC, have been delayed into 2017, and that anecdotally, financing and completing new developments may be getting more challenging. 
Overall, we are pleased with our SHOP performance through the first half of the year. We're, therefore, raising our full year guidance for SHOP reported cash NOI in the full year same-store asset pool to grow in the range of 1.5% to 3%, up from our 1% to 3% range previously communicated. Strong rate growth and lower year-over-year occupancy, led by our high barrier to entry markets is expected to fuel this NOI performance. 
Let me close out the segment review with our MOB business, which represents 20% of Ventas' overall NOI. MOB cash NOI in its 353 property quarterly same-store pool grew nearly 1% in the second quarter and increased 2.3% in the first half. Both the second quarter and the first half benefited from in-place rent escalations and continued cost productivity from the Lillibridge platform, partially offset by lower occupancy. For the balance of the year, we are actively filling the leasing pipeline to backfill move outs and to cover increased repair and maintenance cost expected in the back half of the year. For the full year 2016, we continue to forecast the MOB segment will grow same-store cash NOI for the full year asset pool in the range of 1% to 2%. 
Turning now to our overall financial results. This was a very busy and productive quarter for Ventas. In the second quarter, we generated strong FFO growth, reduced refinancing risk while capitalizing on favorable market conditions and further strengthened our credit profile. 
First, our earnings growth. Second quarter 2016 normalized FFO totaled $1.04 per fully diluted share, representing 7% growth on a comparable basis over the second quarter of 2015. This strong year-over-year growth was driven by the carryover impact of 2015 investments, including Ardent, together with new year-to-date investments in 2016 and second quarter same-store NOI growth. 
Ventas made $65 million in new investments in the second quarter of 2016, including $30 million of acquisitions and $35 million of development and redevelopment spending during the quarter. We strengthened our balance sheet in Q2 through the issuance of a total of 3.5 million shares of common stock under our ATM for gross proceeds of approximately $232 million. We also capitalized on the strong debt capital markets and took refinancing risk off the table in the quarter. In June, we tendered, and ultimately, retired in full the $550 million 1.55% senior notes maturing in September 2016. The September note was retired principally through the issuance of a $400 million 3/8 7-year unsecured note. Demand for Ventas' debt offering was very high, with the order book 7.5x oversubscribed. 
As a result of this cumulative capital activity during the quarter, we have an even healthier balance sheet and excellent liquidity. The company's net debt to EBITDA ratio improved from 6.1x at year-end 2015 to 5.8x at the end of the second quarter, ahead of our expectations. We have lowered gross debt by nearly $300 million since the beginning of the year. Our fixed charge coverage is exceptionally strong at 4.6x, and our debt to total capitalization is outstanding at 30%. 
And we did not stop there. Following the quarter-end, we elected to lock in our attractive return and accretion on the Wexford acquisition through a block equity issuance. Concurrent with deal announcement in early July, Ventas sold 10.3 million shares of common stock for total proceeds of $736 million at an issuance price of approximately $72 per share. We plan to hold the proceeds in cash until the Wexford's closing. The temporary FFO cost of the strategy is $0.01 a month, notably dampening our Q3 FFO per share, assuming a Q4 Wexford closing. We believe the short run dilution of pre-funding is more than offset by the longer-term value creation of this strategy. 
And that's a good segue to our full year guidance for the company. We are updating our normalized FFO per share guidance for 2016 to a range of $4.05 to $4.13, representing 3% to 5% growth over 2015 on a comparable basis. Put simply, the modest $0.02 revision from previous guidance reflects paying $0.04 for the certainty that comes with the Wexford equity pre-funding, as well as Q2 deleveraging, partially offset by the accretive impact of Wexford post close. Our second half FFO per share guidance is expected to be lower than our first half results, driven by these same factors. 
Setting aside capital activity, our underlying same-store portfolio performance is solid. On the heels of a healthy first half, we're raising the bottom end of our total 2016 same-store NOI guidance range by 50 basis points. 2016 same-store NOI is now estimated to grow in the range of 2% to 3%, up from the company's previous range of 1.5% to 3%. 
Our guidance continues to assume 2016 asset dispositions of approximately $500 million, inclusive of $75 million in dispositions closed year-to-date. No further material acquisitions, dispositions or capital activity are assumed in guidance. 
In summary, the entire Ventas team is proud of our productive and strong first half of the year and is committed to sustaining our track record of excellence. 
With that, I will ask the operator to please open the call for questions.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: I was hoping you guys good Debbie, but you can speak a little bit about whether your growth expectations. You got into the midpoint does seem to imply a bit of a deceleration and maybe if you can just talk about the confidence level within the range and how you're seeing your REIT strategy playing out. It appears to be working in the primary markets but any change to how that's working out in the other 30%, the secondary and the tertiary markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, we're very pleased with the first half. As I mentioned, we expected to have a strong first half in a way we did, and it really has been fueled by the injury I keep referring to those key coastal markets like New York, like LA, like Boston, w
componenttext: First of all, we're very pleased with the first half. As I mentioned, we expected to have a strong first half in a way we did, and it really has been fueled by the injury I keep referring to those key coastal markets like New York, like LA, like Boston, which have continued to grow mid-single-digit. On the back of that, as you reference, the rate-driven strategy, you see the strongest rates and NOI growth in those markets, and that's very much as expected. So we're really pleased with that. At the same time, the construction impact, again, very much in line with the initial guidance we gave in February and the framework we put around that. Indeed, the impact of the new units coming online is on the better end of the guidance that we gave in February. And as a consequence, net, net that, when you step back and look at the performance -- portfolio in the first half, 2.5% growth above the midpoint of the guidance towards the higher end. So we feel very good about the first half, and that is the core reason why we are raising the guidance for the back half of the year. The reason for the range continues to be very consistent with that framework of engine room performance continue to drive forward and potential variability, depending on the impact of new construction, and that's the reason for the range in the back half. But fundamentally, the confidence in that guidance is solid.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the growth to accelerate or decelerate, looking at the third into the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And do you expect the growth to accelerate or decelerate, looking at the third into the fourth quarter?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think you can see a scenario if you stick to what we had in the first half to be at the higher end again as we were in the first half. The lower end of that will be dictated by supply. And the big question is, when are those new units coming
componenttext: Well, look, I think you can see a scenario if you stick to what we had in the first half to be at the higher end again as we were in the first half. The lower end of that will be dictated by supply. And the big question is, when are those new units coming online? What does that look like? One of the things we've seen and others have commented on is deferring new units coming online into 2017, that would obviously be good. That gives more time for absorption of existing inventory. And if that were to happen, we expect to be at the higher end. But it will be a function of when inventory comes online and what the impact is.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

If you can give us any color on what types of assets you're looking to sell and maybe why exactly the buyer pulls and cap rate expectations. headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we have $500 million in the guidance for the year. As you already point out, $75 million year to date, we feel very confident in that guidance for the year. The markets are good. We've said before, and continues to be true, the focus areas includ
componenttext: Sure. So we have $500 million in the guidance for the year. As you already point out, $75 million year to date, we feel very confident in that guidance for the year. The markets are good. We've said before, and continues to be true, the focus areas include MOBs, some senior housing and potential loan repayments. And we have line of sight very much for the guidance number of $500 million. Obviously back end weighted. So it has an impact in the back end but feeling good about that guidance number.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] Rose from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from [indiscernible] Rose from Citi.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Michael Bilerman here. I'm wondering if you can talk about Wexford and you've commented having worked on it many times and having a lot of knowledge. And so when you're presented with that, you were able to act fast. And you called out 3 var
componenttext: It's actually Michael Bilerman here. I'm wondering if you can talk about Wexford and you've commented having worked on it many times and having a lot of knowledge. And so when you're presented with that, you were able to act fast. And you called out 3 variables that ultimately lead you to win. The trust that you had with the other parties, the structure that you presented and then the common capital market. And I recognize stars have to align for any deal to occur, and you've said that before. How would you rank those 3 variables as we think about other transactions that will come -- could happen? So how important is the capital market side versus the trust the seller has and the structure that you're creating? How would you weight those and rank them?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the biggest factors, as I mentioned in my remarks, Michael, is that we believe that we're entering in a good risk-adjusted return and that the assets are going to produce reliable growth and income. So that is the #1 factor in all deals, defi
componenttext: Well, one of the biggest factors, as I mentioned in my remarks, Michael, is that we believe that we're entering in a good risk-adjusted return and that the assets are going to produce reliable growth and income. So that is the #1 factor in all deals, definitely. And obviously, our funding costs are critical, because we are here to add value for shareholders, and so appropriate capital markets is extremely important. And I would say having a good relationship with Blackstone and the Wexford management team is a helpful, facilitated factor in the transaction as well. And the structure is always, I would say, a helpful factor, but normally, it's not this positive. It's really those cash flows. And here, when we look at Wexford and these are new assets, they're Class A assets, and about 3/4 of the NOI is from tenants who have investment-grade ratings, have billion-plus market caps, have a AA rated -- or universities. That, to us, is a really good risk-adjusted return when you're looking at 10-plus year length of lease maturities. And so everything came together, I think, in a really positive way. The fact that we've looked at the deal before, I think really shows our discipline and patience, and that's really how we operate here. And so we're very excited about it and I hope that answers your question.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it does. And I was wondering, how do you debate, there's been some that have sort of compared this to some of the core life science markets, where cap rates are in the 4 to 5s. And then taking it one step further that if Wexford came at a high 6s, it
componenttext: No, it does. And I was wondering, how do you debate, there's been some that have sort of compared this to some of the core life science markets, where cap rates are in the 4 to 5s. And then taking it one step further that if Wexford came at a high 6s, it has to be lower quality or there has to have much higher risk involved in that portfolio, because it's commanding a cap rate that is significantly in excess of where stuff in Cambridge or San Francisco would trade. How do you sort of defend some of that criticism?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say the following. The Wexford business is a very institutional business. It matches incredibly well with the Ventas' business model. And I do think that there is a natural segmentation, frankly, between this part of the business and the Cam
componenttext: Well, I would say the following. The Wexford business is a very institutional business. It matches incredibly well with the Ventas' business model. And I do think that there is a natural segmentation, frankly, between this part of the business and the Cambridge, et cetera, cost our market strategy. I would say to you that the reliability of these cash flows is extremely high, and they will produce this reliable growth and income that Ventas prizes and that our investors prize. But it's a different game in Cambridge, really. And there's excellent players like Alexandria and Blackstone, who will invest in those 4, 5 cap rate markets and deal with the turnover and all of that. But Wexford sits with the Ventas business model, and that's really the key thing. It is a very reliable, consistent growth in income, with institutional tenants and even cross-selling opportunities with medical assets as well. So that, I think, if anything, the deal is just a good one for our shareholders, plain and simple.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just last one for me. Can you talk a little bit about sort of the Ardent pipeline and where you stand now that the managers under EIG and where do they stand in terms of growing the platform capital source? When should we expect additional acqu
componenttext: Great. And just last one for me. Can you talk a little bit about sort of the Ardent pipeline and where you stand now that the managers under EIG and where do they stand in terms of growing the platform capital source? When should we expect additional acquisitions there?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, as you know, we are big believers in the growth opportunity in our hospital business, we're really happy with the Ardent investment and the Ardent management team. It is performing very well. We've said all along that this is a big, long-term,
componenttext: Yes. Well, as you know, we are big believers in the growth opportunity in our hospital business, we're really happy with the Ardent investment and the Ardent management team. It is performing very well. We've said all along that this is a big, long-term, secular opportunity, and we want to build a great business here. We've also said we're going to be very selective, and we are. We want high quality, with all the characteristics that we've talked about over and over again, and we think we can scale this Ardent business. But it is a business where we will stay selective, and therefore, difficult to predict when transactions will meet the hurdle and we'll have something to announce. But really, we feel optimistic about the opportunities and feel really good about the Ardent investment and, hopefully, more to follow at the appropriate time.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Nick Yulico from UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Nick Yulico from UBS.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a few questions on your senior housing operating segment. If I look, your portfolio has been kind of steadily losing occupancy quarter-by-quarter over the last year. Would suggest you probably can hold rate growth high forever. So you also cited sup
componenttext: I had a few questions on your senior housing operating segment. If I look, your portfolio has been kind of steadily losing occupancy quarter-by-quarter over the last year. Would suggest you probably can hold rate growth high forever. So you also cited supply being an issue for 30% of your portfolio. So I guess, I'm wondering, big picture here, how does senior housing growth get better in coming years? It seems like it should be getting worse.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Nick, if I step back big picture, I'll emphasize again the value proposition of senior housing. We are bullish on senior housing, short, medium, long-term, because when you look at the services that seniors get in senior housing communities, economi
componenttext: Well, Nick, if I step back big picture, I'll emphasize again the value proposition of senior housing. We are bullish on senior housing, short, medium, long-term, because when you look at the services that seniors get in senior housing communities, economically to replicate that at home is 2x as expensive, not to mention the social benefits of being part of a community, which are proven to be enhancing and extending life. And therefore, there's a great product offering here where affordability, importantly, affordability, if you look at net worth among seniors, affordability of senior housing is not the gating issue. They can afford comfortably, on average, to enter senior housing. So that, together with, of course, the aging population, the megatrend of longevity as a huge tailwind to this business give me and us confidence in that business. Now, within that, as you already point out, we've been driving a rate strategy in light of that value proposition. We think that's a smart move. It really is very much predicated on the annual rent letter. And that increase we saw this year, which was among the highest we've had has held nicely and is proving out to be a good strategy. At the same time, we are being sensitive to the occupancy impacts. And this is proving out to be a good formula. One that will be dynamic though. I mean, we will make sure we're managing well, because it is a more complex equation between rate and occupancy. But nonetheless, we like where we are. The strategy is proving out very much in line with where we expect it to be. And then short, medium, long-term, this is a great business.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Bob. I guess just to follow up, I think you said that, you've been saying that your second quarter is one of your toughest comps, and I wasn't sure if that was due to occupancy or otherwise. But if I look at what you had, over 91% oc
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Bob. I guess just to follow up, I think you said that, you've been saying that your second quarter is one of your toughest comps, and I wasn't sure if that was due to occupancy or otherwise. But if I look at what you had, over 91% occupancy in the third and fourth quarters last year, it seems like you also have some tough comps in the back half of the year. So maybe can you just explain how we should be thinking about your guidance and what it assumes for, I don't know, I forget, this has been mentioned yet, but occupancy, whether it's sort of declining year-over-year, if that's built into the guidance in the back half of the year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. So looking at the guidance for the year in the back half, what we expect to happen is we narrowed the gap, if you look year-over-year, in terms of occupancy, relative to the first quarter to the second. That said, still lower than last year.
componenttext: Right. Okay. So looking at the guidance for the year in the back half, what we expect to happen is we narrowed the gap, if you look year-over-year, in terms of occupancy, relative to the first quarter to the second. That said, still lower than last year. We hope to continue to narrow that gap. But on a full year basis, occupancy will be below prior year. However, rate, we continue to expect, will be strong and to hold with where we are, and that is really important, in part, to cover costs. And therefore, the paradigm of the P&L is one of revenue growth very much in line with expense growth to deliver the guidance we gave for the year. So that's the P&L profile. I think if you look within construction markets, you'll see a different dynamic, where we still see rate growth albeit not as strong, and we do see some occupancy pressure. And so for that 30% of the portfolio, you do see a slightly different P&L. But again, because of the engine room, it's more than offset by the key markets to deliver the overall year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Tyler from Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Tyler from Green Street Advisors.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The triple net assets, the customary growth I guess that I expect from those is more than 2% to 3% range, and you reported 4% in the quarter, exclusively Kindred fee. Didn't seem like there was a ton of role or any role in the portfolio. And I know you me
componenttext: The triple net assets, the customary growth I guess that I expect from those is more than 2% to 3% range, and you reported 4% in the quarter, exclusively Kindred fee. Didn't seem like there was a ton of role or any role in the portfolio. And I know you mentioned escalations, but can you just explain how you got to 4% and maybe why it's running as least so far this year above the normalized pace?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll highlight a few things. One is we mentioned the Kindred deal that we did in April, which as part of that, you recall, we reallocated rent to more productive assets. We saw that in the second quarter. That's a same-store benefit. That contribute
componenttext: Sure. I'll highlight a few things. One is we mentioned the Kindred deal that we did in April, which as part of that, you recall, we reallocated rent to more productive assets. We saw that in the second quarter. That's a same-store benefit. That contributes to the 4%. And will continue to do so as that rent again was reallocated to asset that could sustain that, given the strength of those assets. So that's 1 driver. And then second, we have a couple higher escalators we've talked about Holiday for example, the past, in senior housing business, which we are seeing the benefit of. Again, also expected to continue into the back half when we look at it. So that being place escalators notably with a few significant drivers are really what's underlying that, Kevin.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Holiday rolls off this year, correct?
componenttext: Okay. And Holiday rolls off this year, correct?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our last 4-ish percent escalator is in the -- in 2016, yes.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with the triple-net bucket, Ardent is really a part of that. And CMS was hospital quality star ratings and just on some quick numbers that I looked at it. Looked like the average star rating for Ardent was kind of in the 3 out of 5 range, a
componenttext: Okay. And then with the triple-net bucket, Ardent is really a part of that. And CMS was hospital quality star ratings and just on some quick numbers that I looked at it. Looked like the average star rating for Ardent was kind of in the 3 out of 5 range, and I'm just wondering how you think about that number, just in general, the ratings, but then 3 out of 5 going forward, does it change revenue? Does it have any impact on the way people make their decisions, we're early, but I'm just curious on thoughts on that.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'm so glad you asked that. That did come out this week. And if you eliminate the 20% of hospitals that were not rated, and you look at the percentages, Ardent performed well above average. And in fact, in its market, performed better than the
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'm so glad you asked that. That did come out this week. And if you eliminate the 20% of hospitals that were not rated, and you look at the percentages, Ardent performed well above average. And in fact, in its market, performed better than the competition. So we were pleased with the outcomes. I know that the management team there is focused ultimately on certainly having everything 3 and above. And ideally, everything in at least a 4, but that's a rarefied [indiscernible] . So we were happy with Ardent's performance and particularly in its market that it is outperforming the competition on quality ratings.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then the last one I had, Bob, just going back to SHOP for a second, and the other more tertiary markets, the 500 bps of occupancy decline was I guess higher than I would have thought. And I'm just wondering, is there anything more than just supply? Or is it really supply specific? It sounds like you're attributing most of it to the new competition, but is there any operational missteps or anything operator-specific that might be in there as well?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, because we are very transparent and almost all -- virtually all of our SHOP assets are in same-store, there's a redevelopment asset that is bringing down that number, which is the principal driver. As it goes through significant redevelopment and,
componenttext: Kevin, because we are very transparent and almost all -- virtually all of our SHOP assets are in same-store, there's a redevelopment asset that is bringing down that number, which is the principal driver. As it goes through significant redevelopment and, of course, redevelopment can both suppress as well as, over time, increase same-store performance, so that's what's really happening there.

componenttext: Yes, it's a tiny pool. It's a tiny pool.

componenttext: Our guidance would certainly suggest though.

componenttext: The math of the guidance, Rich, would say it's going to grow in the back half. And certainly, our experience in the first half supports that again because of the quality of the hydrating market momentum. So that's why we raised the lower end for the full year.
