headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, do you have an opinion today as you see it if the new cardiac bundling programs would be more or less damaging to the skilled nursing business versus CJR?
componenttext: Debbie, do you have an opinion today as you see it if the new cardiac bundling programs would be more or less damaging to the skilled nursing business versus CJR?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a loaded question. I would say you wrote an interesting note on that, and I did mention that the value-based payment, the transition to value-based payment is accelerating with the addition of this new cardiac bundle that's going to be mandat
componenttext: Well, that's a loaded question. I would say you wrote an interesting note on that, and I did mention that the value-based payment, the transition to value-based payment is accelerating with the addition of this new cardiac bundle that's going to be mandatory in, I think, 98 markets in 2017 on top of the CJR. We don't even know what markets the 98 are yet, and so there's a limited amount of clarity we can provide. But overall, the bundling initiative, which will continue to come as part of the evolution of the health care system, in general, should savor high-quality hospitals. And while longer term may present opportunities for the winner in skilled nursing, in the near term will likely create some pressures on the business. In terms of quantifying it, again, too early to say. It's even too early to say on the CJR because we've only been in it since April.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And then last question from me, on Wexford. Do you -- so you mentioned 10% marketshare. So you expect to just traffic in that corner of life science a.k.a. university-type business? Or do you see yourself also kind of trafficking in the
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And then last question from me, on Wexford. Do you -- so you mentioned 10% marketshare. So you expect to just traffic in that corner of life science a.k.a. university-type business? Or do you see yourself also kind of trafficking in the more conventional space, like the research hubs of Boston and San Diego and so on?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, one direct answer and one clarification. We are focused on building the university-based institutional part of that business, which is really Wexford Square Business and where, they are far and away, the leader in that market, so great brand, t
componenttext: Yes. Well, one direct answer and one clarification. We are focused on building the university-based institutional part of that business, which is really Wexford Square Business and where, they are far and away, the leader in that market, so great brand, trusted developer. And we believe there's opportunities there to grow that business and have some on the drawing board now as I mentioned. And that's really where we're going to focus. And the clarification is that these 11 universities that we're already doing business with in the Wexford portfolio, so 11 universities that are tenants, they account for 10% of all university life science R&D spending, which is amazing when you think about it. That this pool of tenants account for 10%. So our strategy will really to be to grow with those leading research universities and then also kind of target the next 20 or so institutions in terms of research and development. So we think we can grow with the tenants we have, and we have those development sites, most of which are in those markets. And then we also have additional institutions that are top-tier research universities that we would hope to grow with as well.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one quick one. Do you ever intend to kind of bring in the management function as well like you have with Lillibridge and so on and fully run it? Or are you satisfied with the current structure long-term?
componenttext: Okay. And just one quick one. Do you ever intend to kind of bring in the management function as well like you have with Lillibridge and so on and fully run it? Or are you satisfied with the current structure long-term?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually pleased with the structure, and we have a great example of that in our PMB relationship in medical office. Because it's really a really high quality development platform that we have exclusive relationships with to fund and own preleased pr
componenttext: We're actually pleased with the structure, and we have a great example of that in our PMB relationship in medical office. Because it's really a really high quality development platform that we have exclusive relationships with to fund and own preleased premier projects like the Sutter building in California that we are building in downtown San Francisco. So we see Wexford very similar to that, and we think it's a great structure that works for both sides and has worked well for us in the past.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jordan Sadler with KeyBanc Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jordan Sadler with KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on Wexford, similar -- just a follow-up there. How would the exclusive going to work with the Wexford platform? Meaning, will the yields on acquisition be similar to what you paid? Or do you take any development risk at all?
componenttext: So on Wexford, similar -- just a follow-up there. How would the exclusive going to work with the Wexford platform? Meaning, will the yields on acquisition be similar to what you paid? Or do you take any development risk at all?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It'll be, again, similar to what we have with PMB and very straightforward, which is when Wexford has projects, we will work on them together, and we have the exclusive right to fund and own them on market terms.
componenttext: It'll be, again, similar to what we have with PMB and very straightforward, which is when Wexford has projects, we will work on them together, and we have the exclusive right to fund and own them on market terms.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So each asset would be negotiated individually.
componenttext: Okay. So each asset would be negotiated individually.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we would -- I mean, we would expect to have, like we do with PMB, development profit in the deals that we would do with Wexford.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we would -- I mean, we would expect to have, like we do with PMB, development profit in the deals that we would do with Wexford.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that infers that the returns will be better than the stabilized cap rate that you guys paid for the in-place portfolio?
componenttext: Okay. So that infers that the returns will be better than the stabilized cap rate that you guys paid for the in-place portfolio?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: In general, yes. But, of course, if it were fully preleased to a AAA credit, I mean, that would be one thing. And if it were -- it's just like any other type of deal that you look at. It would be market-based, and we will gain the benefits of substantial
componenttext: In general, yes. But, of course, if it were fully preleased to a AAA credit, I mean, that would be one thing. And if it were -- it's just like any other type of deal that you look at. It would be market-based, and we will gain the benefits of substantial amount of the development profit.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you would buy something that was nonstabilized and let them lease it up, like it would have an anchor tenant, for instance?
componenttext: So you would buy something that was nonstabilized and let them lease it up, like it would have an anchor tenant, for instance?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's honestly, it's like everything else. For example, we are developing this premier MOB in downtown San Francisco that's anchored by a AA-rated credit Sutter Health, and we make a decision on that with x amount of preleasing based on our expertise
componenttext: Well, it's honestly, it's like everything else. For example, we are developing this premier MOB in downtown San Francisco that's anchored by a AA-rated credit Sutter Health, and we make a decision on that with x amount of preleasing based on our expertise, knowing that, that -- and this is why the businesses are very similar. You have strong institutional support from AA-rated institutions for a big component of the building, and that anchor tenant drives the demand for the building to fill in the spaces that are not preleased by that institution, it's exactly parallel. And so every deal is different with PMB, and every deal will be different with Wexford. But we're very excited about the prospects, and as I said, have some things on the drawing board that we think are very attractive.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how does the Wexford portfolio and that business roll up within the organizational structure at Ventas? Is that going to be under the MOB Lillibridge umbrella or other?
componenttext: And how does the Wexford portfolio and that business roll up within the organizational structure at Ventas? Is that going to be under the MOB Lillibridge umbrella or other?

componenttextpreview: It'll be -- it's direct line.
componenttext: It'll be -- it's direct line.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. One clarification. On this -- on the SHOP portfolio, REVPOR, it -- sequentially, it looked like it was flat or maybe down a little bit, is there anything going on in that? I know that the increases in the portfolio and rate came through, I think, in
componenttext: Okay. One clarification. On this -- on the SHOP portfolio, REVPOR, it -- sequentially, it looked like it was flat or maybe down a little bit, is there anything going on in that? I know that the increases in the portfolio and rate came through, I think, in the first quarter. But anything that would have driven it to be flatter as opposed to rising?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's flat as you say sequentially and approximately 4% year-over-year. The big benefit of the rate bump happens in the first quarter, where the majority of the increase comes. And then if you look at typically, you'll see some small drift from there,
componenttext: Yes, it's flat as you say sequentially and approximately 4% year-over-year. The big benefit of the rate bump happens in the first quarter, where the majority of the increase comes. And then if you look at typically, you'll see some small drift from there, just through dynamic of move-ins and activity associated with that. So I wouldn't really beat into anything there, Jordan.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's normal.
componenttext: It's normal.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Carroll with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Carroll with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: With regards to the Wexford platform, Debbie, I know you highlighted several near-term development opportunities that you guys are tracking, but how many projects are you comfortable pursuing at once with that platform right now?
componenttext: With regards to the Wexford platform, Debbie, I know you highlighted several near-term development opportunities that you guys are tracking, but how many projects are you comfortable pursuing at once with that platform right now?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like everything else, it'll be a function of what's available, and we'll be opportunistic and we will -- we are a large company, I mean, we are a $36 billion, $37 billion company. So, if any one project is $100 million, $150 million, I think we could cert
componenttext: Like everything else, it'll be a function of what's available, and we'll be opportunistic and we will -- we are a large company, I mean, we are a $36 billion, $37 billion company. So, if any one project is $100 million, $150 million, I think we could certainly manage multiples at one time, assuming we think that they meet our risk-adjusted return expectations. So I like the idea unlike a big office building, for example, you're going to have basically uncorrelated assets under development at one time. You might have1 in with Wash U or 1 with U Penn or something like that. And so those would be uncorrelated. But we are large enough and have the financial strength and flexibility to do multiple projects at one time.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And given the growth prospects that you're tracking right now, how big do you think you can grow that platform over the next 3 to 5 years?
componenttext: And given the growth prospects that you're tracking right now, how big do you think you can grow that platform over the next 3 to 5 years?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we want to be reasonable about the expectations. We are very optimistic about it, but we would imagine that in 5 years, it could be anywhere from 1.5 to 2x. We've certainly scaled the Atria and Lillibridge businesses, but it's always a function agai
componenttext: Well, we want to be reasonable about the expectations. We are very optimistic about it, but we would imagine that in 5 years, it could be anywhere from 1.5 to 2x. We've certainly scaled the Atria and Lillibridge businesses, but it's always a function again of what the opportunities are presented and whether they meet their our capital allocation discipline and whether we think they're going to make money for shareholders.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the last question, can you give us additional color on the company's investment outlook outside of Ardent and Wexford? I mean, what's your specific strategies right now on the MOB and senior housing spaces?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the last question, can you give us additional color on the company's investment outlook outside of Ardent and Wexford? I mean, what's your specific strategies right now on the MOB and senior housing spaces?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John Cobb.We have been very disciplined. We look at hospital space. Like you said, we look that now the life science space with Wexford. We're also focused growing with customers. And you saw the 3 deals this past quarter. We did 2 deals with Li
componenttext:
This is John Cobb.
We have been very disciplined. We look at hospital space. Like you said, we look that now the life science space with Wexford. We're also focused growing with customers. And you saw the 3 deals this past quarter. We did 2 deals with Lillibridge and 1 with PMB. And we're focused on growing our customers and doing some development and redevelopment.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So independent senior housing investment will be smaller transactions with your existing relationships?
componenttext: So independent senior housing investment will be smaller transactions with your existing relationships?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It depends on the opportunities. Of course, we want to help our customers grow. We want to help them do tuck-ins and fill in markets and so on. And in addition?
componenttext: It depends on the opportunities. Of course, we want to help our customers grow. We want to help them do tuck-ins and fill in markets and so on. And in addition?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if we saw a Class A portfolio that had -- that had at Ventas Advantage, we would be aggressive. And if it made sense for us and our customers.
componenttext: Yes. I think if we saw a Class A portfolio that had -- that had at Ventas Advantage, we would be aggressive. And if it made sense for us and our customers.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Kim with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last year and again today, you made a very solid case hospitals becoming a big opportunity for your company. And then you sort of pivot with the acquisition of Wexford. Can you elaborate in how difficult it is to source high-quality hospitals especially w
componenttext: Last year and again today, you made a very solid case hospitals becoming a big opportunity for your company. And then you sort of pivot with the acquisition of Wexford. Can you elaborate in how difficult it is to source high-quality hospitals especially when you're competing against the communities and HCAs of the world?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We feel very optimistic about the longer term opportunities to scale Ardent and build a high-quality hospital business. This sector is gigantic. It's a 300-plus billion dollar space. It's consolidating, and importantly, I truly believe, in my nerdy Univer
componenttext: We feel very optimistic about the longer term opportunities to scale Ardent and build a high-quality hospital business. This sector is gigantic. It's a 300-plus billion dollar space. It's consolidating, and importantly, I truly believe, in my nerdy University of Chicago way, that assets will flow to the most efficient owners, and that we are such an efficient owner with significant expertise. And so I feel very confident about it, and we're working hard on it. All investments are really based on opportunity set though. And we have said over and over that in the hospital business in particular, we will be selective on quality. And so the theses remains intact. In fact, it continues to be very exciting to us, and it's really a matter of time, I think, which is a little bit more unpredictable, but we feel good about it.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. In terms of dispositions, can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of pricing in the private market? Historically, health care REITs have been priced better. And it seems like this year your cost of capital has improved, but you're also being
componenttext: Okay. In terms of dispositions, can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of pricing in the private market? Historically, health care REITs have been priced better. And it seems like this year your cost of capital has improved, but you're also being a little more disciplined. So what are you seeing as far as the private market buyers?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Heck, we've always been disciplined. There is a deep market with new entrants who want to invest in medical office and senior housing. They're very financeable assets. And the good thing is you point out with our cost of capital and just overall strength
componenttext: Heck, we've always been disciplined. There is a deep market with new entrants who want to invest in medical office and senior housing. They're very financeable assets. And the good thing is you point out with our cost of capital and just overall strength of our business is that we are sellers by choice. So what we are trying to do is create options in terms of sale and continue to refine our portfolio and do some routine capital recycling. And so I think that's all to the good. And so we feel right on track with our guidance and feel confident about the market for those assets.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I may have missed this, but did you provide guidance on CapEx on your disposition?
componenttext: I may have missed this, but did you provide guidance on CapEx on your disposition?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it really depends, as I said, we are sellers by choice, and so we have a pool of opportunities that we can decide whether to do or not. And so the cap rates will depend on what we decide to ultimately pull the trigger on in terms of disposition.
componenttext: Well, it really depends, as I said, we are sellers by choice, and so we have a pool of opportunities that we can decide whether to do or not. And so the cap rates will depend on what we decide to ultimately pull the trigger on in terms of disposition.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the final question on your SHOP guidance. Today, we got a weak GDP print of just 1.2%, which is good for your share price, I suppose but probably challenging for the environment of low our fundamentals. What happens to your strategy if we e
componenttext: Okay. And then the final question on your SHOP guidance. Today, we got a weak GDP print of just 1.2%, which is good for your share price, I suppose but probably challenging for the environment of low our fundamentals. What happens to your strategy if we enter into a 0 growth or a recessionary environment and is that factored into your guidance at all?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. We are in a relatively Goldilocks environment for REITs, in general, I would say, and for Ventas in particular, as I mentioned. We had been in a slow growth in the U.S. economy for a while. That -- what I would say is that in the financial crisis a
componenttext: Right. We are in a relatively Goldilocks environment for REITs, in general, I would say, and for Ventas in particular, as I mentioned. We had been in a slow growth in the U.S. economy for a while. That -- what I would say is that in the financial crisis and recession, senior housing was the only real estate asset class that continued to show positive NOI growth. Our business is -- our guidance is based upon a continued low-single-digit GDP growth. However, what I would say is, because of our long-term leases, if you look at the kinds of things we're doing with Wexford, if you look at our business mix and our business model, we have inelastic demand, growing demographics, long-term leases with escalations, where our business really should and has in the past in recessionary environment, continue to produce reliable income. And I would expect that going forward.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Agreed. But in the last recession, you were most, mostly triple net. And this time around, you have a higher percentage of operating portfolio assets. So I'm just wondering, in this  if we're going to a recession time this period, how confident are you th
componenttext: Agreed. But in the last recession, you were most, mostly triple net. And this time around, you have a higher percentage of operating portfolio assets. So I'm just wondering, in this  if we're going to a recession time this period, how confident are you that, that part of your portfolio is going to be resilient?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think resiliency is exactly the right word, and I think that what Ventas continues to offer to investors, which is highly valuable, is a very protected downside on cash flows with significant upside from internal and external growth. And that is more va
componenttext:
I think resiliency is exactly the right word, and I think that what Ventas continues to offer to investors, which is highly valuable, is a very protected downside on cash flows with significant upside from internal and external growth. And that is more valuable now than ever. 
Okay, we have time for a couple of more.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you step back, there's a strong correlation, as I've described, our engine room markets versus those that has some construction exposure, there's high correlation between primary and secondary markets, and that is the performance you see in the
componenttext: I think if you step back, there's a strong correlation, as I've described, our engine room markets versus those that has some construction exposure, there's high correlation between primary and secondary markets, and that is the performance you see in the secondary markets does have a number of those supply challenge markets in it. Witness Indianapolis and Knoxville, for example, to pick a couple of specifics. Whereas the primary markets, I talk about New York and LA and Boston all the time, clearly those are primary. If you step back, I think, from a portfolio point of view, that's a little bit of an artificial segmentation that's really NIC driven. If we step back and like our portfolio and are looking at ways to be able to, for example, help to continue to drive operational excellence, help invest behind that, help them build scale. And even in some of these markets, we continue to see that we gain share in those markets because we have great assets that are run really, really well. So it's not a matter of reacting to the here and now but thinking about how can I grow short, medium and long-term, and we have not only the assets but the operators to do that.

componenttext: Well, everything is a candidate for disposition. And as I mentioned, with the portfolio that we have, we want to continue to think about where we can optimize the portfolio, where we can recycle capital and we want to optimize that. And so we review the portfolio on a regular basis and think about the best ways to create pools of potential disposition candidates. And I would say SHOP and MOBs are in that pool, along with loan repayment, as Bob mentioned. And so I will just think about it that way.

componenttext: In no specific order, I would say, as John mentioned, helping customers grow and being a good partner, development and redevelopment, which will be with Wexford, with Atria, et cetera, with Sutter and PMB, and then putting capital to work supporting Ardent's growth within the hospital space. So those are key capital allocation priorities.

Well, there's new staffing rules and things and enforcement activities of that staffing that has -- have increased costs, and the operators are getting kind of up the curve on that, and that's what I mean.  
We care about our investors, and I'd just like to close by saying that we know the demand for health care and senior housing products and services is going to increase exponentially as people live longer and our aging population grows. With our diverse high-quality portfolio, our leading platforms for growth and our cohesive team, we believe that Ventas and our shareholders will benefit from this wave of oncoming demand and increasing life expectancies. We really appreciate your time and interest in our company, your continued support of the company and nothing makes us happier than making money for you. So thank you again.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Christelle. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas' Conference Call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended June 30, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain
componenttext:
Thanks, Christelle. Good morning, and welcome to the Ventas' Conference Call to review the company's announcement today regarding its results for the quarter ended June 30, 2016. As we start, let me express that all projections and predictions and certain other statements to be made during this conference call may be considered forward-looking statements within the meaning of the federal securities laws. These projections, predictions and statements are based on management's current beliefs as well as on a number of assumptions concerning future events. These forward-looking statements are subject to many risks, uncertainties and contingencies, and stockholders and others should recognize that actual results may differ materially from the company's expectations, whether expressed or implied. We refer you to the company's reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015, and the company's other reports filed periodically with the SEC for a discussion of these forward-looking statements and other factors that could affect these forward-looking statements. Many of these factors are beyond the control of the company and its management. The information being provided today is as of this date only, and Ventas expressly disclaims any obligation to release publicly any updates or revisions to any forward-looking statements to reflect any changes in expectations. 
Please note that quantitative reconciliations between each non-GAAP financial measure referenced on this conference call and its most directly comparable GAAP measure as well as the company's supplemental disclosure schedule are available in the Investor Relations section of our website at www.ventasreit.com. 
I will now turn the call over to Debra A. Cafaro, Chairman and CEO of the company.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants, and welcome to the Ventas Second Quarter Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to report on our strong results from our diverse high-quality port
componenttext:
Thank you, Ryan, and good morning to all of our shareholders and other participants, and welcome to the Ventas Second Quarter Earnings Call. We are delighted to be here with our colleagues to report on our strong results from our diverse high-quality portfolio, discuss our pending investment in life sciences and medical real estate and provide color on macro trends. Following my remarks, our CFO, Bob Probst, will review our segment performance and financial results and walk through our full year guidance before we welcome your questions. 
We have great momentum at Ventas. Building off our superior properties, platforms and people, we extended our long track record of excellence this quarter. If you invest in Ventas for reliable growth and income on a strong balance sheet, then this is a good quarter for you. 
Leading these results, we delivered $1.04 in normalized FFO per share, representing 7% year-over-year comparable growth. And we remain on track for 3% to 5% normalized FFO growth this year. We were opportunistic in access to debt and equity capital markets, again demonstrating our commitments to financial strength and flexibility as well as our expertise in capital markets activity. 
As you know, we love cash flow, because it enables us to reinvest in our business and pay you a dividend. Our strong and secure dividend yield of nearly 4% is very attractive and has plenty of room to continue to grow. 
Our strong performance is fueled by our market position as the exciting intersection of health care and real estate to large and dynamic industries with powerful fundamentals and growth prospects. Within this attractive space, our incredible team has made strategic decisions and executed our strategy with sustained excellence. As a result, we have differentiated our portfolio and our company, benefited our shareholders and shaped Ventas for continued success. 
Recent examples of our disciplined capital allocation moves include our successful spin-off of most of our skilled nursing business and our entry into the large growing hospital space with Ardent, both completed last year. The elevation and evolution of our business continued this year with our recent deal to announce -- to acquire $1.5 billion in high-quality life science and medical real estate operated by best-in-class developer, Wexford. We believe the Wexford deal is both financially and strategically attractive. With the going in cash yield on stabilized assets of 6.8%, it is a wonderful fit with our goal of delivering reliable growth and income through cycles. This investment represents an accretive institutional quality entry into the large and growing health care-driven research and development space. It adds an adjacent business line that further diversifies our portfolio and cash flows and adds a large component of private pay NOI to our business mix. The powerful combination of attractive properties, superior platforms and outstanding people creates the Ventas Advantage. All 3 are on display with the Wexford deal. 
The 25 Wexford properties we will acquire are new Class A assets that are environmentally advanced and architecturally appealing. I hope you'll go to our website for a property tour to see this portfolio. The assets are also well leased to highly rated top-tier universities, academic medical centers and research companies, including Yale, U Penn Medicine, Wash U, Duke and Wake Forest. Like other areas of our business, our prospective tenants are market leaders. The universities in our portfolio account for fully 10% of all university life sciences research and development spending in the U.S. That's an outstanding way to enter a new space. It was really fun to travel up and down the East Coast with Ryan recently, visiting these hotbeds of academic and commercial research, cutting-edge medical activity, innovation and education. 
The Wexford acquisition also creates another superior platform for Ventas growth. The Wexford team has a terrific reputation within the sophisticated tight knit community of elite universities. Demand is increasing as universities take difficult decisions about capital allocation. In this environment, combining Ventas' capital with a trusted developer who can deliver complex projects that benefit leading institutions should be a winning formula. 
We have an exclusive pipeline for growth with Wexford, with 2 assets under development coming online in 2017 and 9 development sites available to satisfy growing demand in research hubs anchored by leading universities. We already have identified 1 potential new development project adjacent to U Penn Medical, which could get green lighted soon. We're hopeful we can grow the business like we have with Lillibridge and Atria. 
The Ventas people and culture were once again truly exceptional in the Wexford deal. We have always admired the Wexford business and have worked on it many times in the past. So when we were recently presented with the opportunity to acquire it, we were a knowledgeable buyer with an incredibly fast, sophisticated and interdisciplinary team. With our deep knowledge of the business and assets, substantial trust among the players, a good structure and accommodative capital market, we were able to execute with excellence. If luck is what happens when preparation meets opportunity, then Ventas is lucky indeed. Hats off to the team. And thanks to the many Ventas investors who participated in our Wexford equity funding in July. We sincerely appreciate your support. 
Next, I'd like to comment briefly on the investment market. We are remaining highly selective as we consider investment opportunities in the current market. Our cost of capital has improved significantly, but we will only execute on deals we believe will generate reliable earnings growth at an appropriate risk-adjusted return. Thus, our focus continues to be on committing capital to high-quality hospitals, helping our customers grow and funding selective development and redevelopment projects. With the addition of Wexford, we expect our capital allocation to preleased university-based development projects to represent a larger percentage of our investment pie. We believe strongly in our ability to invest capital across cycles to create value for our investors and customers. This confidence flows from the combination of our advantaged position within 5 and soon to be 6 asset classes, our relationships with market leading customers and platforms and our team's hard-earned experience and skill. 
Before closing, it's worthwhile to spend a few minutes on the macro environment. In the health care arena, we see an acceleration of the transition to value-based payment model. Just this week, CMS announced that it will layer on additional mandatory bundling for cardiac care in 2017. This and other development support our thesis that hospitals are beginning to exert even more influence in post-acute patient care and cost, and that revenue streams for skilled nursing providers will likely remain under pressure in the near term. In the longer term, diversified post-acute care providers like Kindred, who can deliver quality care in a variety of settings, maintain a sound capital structure and adequate liquidity, and enjoy the benefits of scale should have a competitive advantage. 
From an economic and market standpoint, we are benefiting from multiple tailwinds that favor our business, including domestic GDP growth that continues to hover in the low single-digits, a global thirst for yield, the creation of a new REIT global industry classification and historically low long-term borrowing rates. In this environment, U.S. real estate and Ventas should thrive. With our need-based demographically-driven business model, a superb track record of consistent, reliable growth, external investment opportunities, a best-in-class credit profile, a differentiated business mix that is 84% private pay and a secure, nearly 4% dividend, Ventas should continue to be a magnet for investment dollars. 
Now, to talk about our positive quarter, I'm happy to turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Debbie. I'm pleased to report solid earnings growth on an even stronger balance sheet in the second quarter. Let me jump right into the performance of our high-quality health care and senior housing properties, which together delivered same-stor
componenttext:
Thank you Debbie. I'm pleased to report solid earnings growth on an even stronger balance sheet in the second quarter. Let me jump right into the performance of our high-quality health care and senior housing properties, which together delivered same-store cash NOI growth of 3.5% for the nearly 1,200 assets in the company's quarterly same-store total portfolio. Performance in the quarter was led by our triple-net leased business, which accounts for 43% of our NOI. Triple-net reported same-store cash NOI growth was 6.2% in Q2 versus the prior year. Growth in the quarter benefited from a $3.5 million cash fee associated with the previously announced collaborative agreements between Ventas and Kindred. Excluding the Kindred fee, triple-net same-store cash NOI grew 4.1% in the quarter, principally reflecting strong in-place lease escalations. Cash flow coverage in our overall stabilized triple-net lease portfolio for the first quarter of 2016, the latest available quarterly information, improved 10 basis points sequentially to 1.7x. This strong coverage level reflects the quality of our triple-net lease properties and of our operators. Coverage in our triple-net same-store senior housing portfolio remained stable at 1.3x. Coverage trends were supported by low-single-digit EBITDARM growth at the asset level for the trailing 12 months. 
Our decision to spin off the majority of our post-acute portfolio in 2015 continues to be validated. Our remaining post-acute portfolio, where SNFs now represent only 4% of our NOI, demonstrated market leading same-store cash flow coverage at 2x in Q1 of 2016. 
Finally, Ardent triple-net coverage held steady at 3x, and continues to perform well at the assets. Ardent showed positive momentum in top and bottom line key performance indicators in both the first and second quarters. With the strong first half of the year and the majority of lease escalations now in place for 2016, we are pleased to update our forecast for the triple-net segment to grow reported full year same-store NOI in the range of 3.5% to 4%, an increase of 75 basis points at the midpoint. 
We are happy to report another solid quarter in our SHOP portfolio, generating Q2 same-store cash NOI growth of 2.1% versus the prior year. This result is right in line with our expectations and reflects our most challenging year-over-year comparison period in 2015. The framework by which we established our SHOP guidance range for the year is holding up very well in both the second quarter and the first half of the year. And with the first half now under our belt, we have performed at the higher end of our guidance range with H1 growth of 2.5% versus prior year on a reported basis. 
In the second quarter, as expected, our rate-driven strategy continued to fuel our earnings with REVPOR growth of nearly 4%. Our high barrier-to-entry infill coastal markets continued to be the engine room of our overall SHOP portfolio growth in the second quarter. These communities, which represent approximately 70% of our SHOP NOI, grew Q2 same-store NOI mid-single digits on continued strong rate growth. Major coastal markets, including New York, LA and Boston, continued to drive consistently outstanding growth in both rates and NOI in the quarter and the first half. In select markets, we observed the impact of new construction coming online within our relevant trade areas. In these communities, same-store NOI posted low single-digit declines in aggregate, driven by occupancy and wage pressures. Again, this performance is consistent with our framework for the approximately 30% of our SHOP portfolio located in markets with the new construction surplus. 
Construction as a percentage of inventory in our trade areas, as reported by NIC, increased in the quarter by 40 basis points to 4.8%. Importantly, however, the amount of our SHOP NOI that is affected by new supply remains at roughly 30%. We have observed that a significant number of projected openings, as reported by NIC, have been delayed into 2017, and that anecdotally, financing and completing new developments may be getting more challenging. 
Overall, we are pleased with our SHOP performance through the first half of the year. We are, therefore, raising our full year guidance for SHOP reported cash NOI in the full year same-store asset pool to grow in the range of 1.5% to 3%, up from our 1% to 3% range previously communicated. Strong rate growth and lower year-over-year occupancy, led by our high barrier-to-entry markets, is expected to fuel this NOI performance. 
Let me close out the segment review with our MOB business, which represents 20% of Ventas' overall NOI. MOB cash NOI in the 353-property quarterly same-store pool grew nearly 1% in the second quarter and increased 2.3% in the first half. Both the second quarter and the first half benefited from in-place rent escalations and continued cost productivity from the Lillibridge platform, partially offset by lower occupancy. For the balance of the year, we are actively filling the leasing pipeline to backfill budgeted move outs and to cover increased repair and maintenance costs expected in the back half of the year. For the full year 2016, we continue to forecast the MOB segment will grow same-store cash NOI for the full year asset pool in the range of 1% to 2%. 
Turning now to our overall financial results. This was a very busy and productive quarter for Ventas. In the second quarter, we generated strong FFO growth, reduced refinancing risk while capitalizing on favorable market conditions and further strengthened our credit profile. 
First, our earnings growth. Second quarter 2016 normalized FFO totaled $1.04 per fully diluted share, representing 7% growth on a comparable basis over the second quarter of 2015. This strong year-over-year growth was driven by the carryover impact of 2015 investments, including Ardent, together with new year-to-date investments in 2016 and second quarter same-store NOI growth. 
Ventas made $65 million in new investments in the second quarter of 2016, including $30 million of acquisitions and $35 million of development and redevelopment spending during the quarter. We strengthened our balance sheet in Q2 through the issuance of a total of 3.5 million shares of common stock under our ATM for gross proceeds of approximately $232 million. We also capitalized on the strong debt capital markets and took refinancing risk off the table in the quarter. In June, we tendered, and ultimately retired in full the $550 million 1.55% senior notes maturing in September 2016. The September note was retired principally through the issuance of a $400 million 3/8 7-year unsecured note. Demand for Ventas' debt offering was very high, with the order book 7.5x oversubscribed. 
As a result of this cumulative capital activity during the quarter, we have an even healthier balance sheet and excellent liquidity. The company's net debt to EBITDA ratio improved from 6.1x at year-end 2015 to 5.8x at the end of the second quarter, ahead of our expectations. We have lowered gross debt by nearly $300 million since the beginning of the year. Our fixed charge coverage is exceptionally strong at 4.6x, and our debt to total capitalization is outstanding at 30%. 
And we did not stop there. Following the quarter-end, we elected to lock in our attractive return and accretion on the Wexford acquisition through a block equity issuance. Concurrent with deal announcement in early July, Ventas sold 10.3 million shares of common stock for total proceeds of $736 million at an issuance price of approximately $72 per share. We plan to hold the proceeds in cash until the Wexford closing. The temporary FFO cost of the strategy is $0.01 a month, notably dampening our Q3 FFO per share, assuming a Q4 Wexford closing. We believe the short run dilution of pre-funding is more than offset by the longer-term value creation of this strategy. 
And that's a good segue to our full year guidance for the company. We are updating our normalized FFO per share guidance for 2016 to a range of $4.05 to $4.13, representing 3% to 5% growth over 2015 on a comparable basis. Put simply, the modest $0.02 revision from previous guidance reflects paying $0.04 for the certainty that comes with the Wexford equity pre-funding as well as Q2 deleveraging, partially offset by the accretive impact of Wexford post close. Our second half FFO per share guidance is expected to be lower than our first half results, driven by these same factors. 
Setting aside capital activity, our underlying same-store portfolio performance is solid. On the heels of a healthy first half, we're raising the bottom end of our total 2016 same-store NOI guidance range by 50 basis points. 2016 same-store NOI is now estimated to grow in the range of 2% to 3%, up from the company's previous range of 1.5% to 3%. 
Our guidance continues to assume 2016 asset dispositions of approximately $500 million, inclusive of $75 million in dispositions closed year-to-date. No further material acquisitions, dispositions or capital activity are assumed in guidance. 
In summary, the entire Ventas team is proud of our productive and strong first half of the year and is committed to sustaining our track record of excellence. 
With that, I will ask the operator to please open the call for questions.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, we're very pleased with the first half. And as I mentioned, we expected to have a strong first half and we did, and it really has been fueled by the injury I keep referring to those key coastal markets like New York, like LA, like Bost
componenttext: Well, first of all, we're very pleased with the first half. And as I mentioned, we expected to have a strong first half and we did, and it really has been fueled by the injury I keep referring to those key coastal markets like New York, like LA, like Boston, which have continued to grow mid-single-digits. On the back of that, as you referenced, the rate-driven strategy, you see the strongest rates and NOI growth in those markets, and that's very much as expected. So we're really pleased with that. At the same time, the construction impact, again, very much in line with the initial guidance we gave in February and the framework we put around that. Indeed, the impact of the new units coming online is on the better end of the guidance that we gave in February. And as a consequence, net, net, net, when you step back and look at the portfolio in the first half, 2.5% growth above the midpoint of the guidance towards the higher end. So we feel very good about the first half and that is the core reason why we are raising the guidance for the back half of the year. The reason for the range continues to be very consistent with that framework of engine room performance continue to drive forward and potential variability, depending on the impact of new construction, and that's the reason for the range in the back half. But fundamentally, the confidence in the guidance is solid.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the growth to accelerate or decelerate, looking at the third into the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And do you expect the growth to accelerate or decelerate, looking at the third into the fourth quarter?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, look, I think you can see a scenario if you stick to what we had in the first half to be at the higher end again as we were in the first half. The lower end of that will be dictated by supply. And the big question is, when are those new units coming
componenttext: Well, look, I think you can see a scenario if you stick to what we had in the first half to be at the higher end again as we were in the first half. The lower end of that will be dictated by supply. And the big question is, when are those new units coming online? What does that look like? One of the things we've seen and others have commented on is deferring new units coming online into 2017, that would obviously be good. That gives more time for absorption of existing inventory. And if that were to happen, we expect to be at the higher end. But it will really be a function of when that inventory comes online and what the impact is.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a second question on dispositions. You still have a fair amount left to do relative to your guidance. If you can give us any color on what types of assets you're looking to sell and maybe why exactly the buyer pulls and the cap
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a second question on dispositions. You still have a fair amount left to do relative to your guidance. If you can give us any color on what types of assets you're looking to sell and maybe why exactly the buyer pulls and the cap rate expectations. And are you looking to monetize any of those [indiscernible] assets beat the secondary or tertiary markets?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we have $500 million in the guidance for the year. As you already pointed out, $75 million year to date, we feel very confident in that guidance for the year. The markets are good. We've said before, and continues to be true, the focus areas incl
componenttext: Sure. So we have $500 million in the guidance for the year. As you already pointed out, $75 million year to date, we feel very confident in that guidance for the year. The markets are good. We've said before, and continues to be true, the focus areas include MOBs, some senior housing and potential loan repayments. And we have line of sight very much for the guidance number of $500 million. Obviously back end weighted. So it has an impact in the back end but feeling good about that guidance number.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Smedes Rose from Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Smedes Rose from Citi.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. it's actually Michael Bilerman here. Debbie, I was wondering if you can talk about Wexford and you commented having worked on it many times and having a lot of knowledge. And so when you're presented with it, you were able to act fast. And then you
componenttext: Great. it's actually Michael Bilerman here. Debbie, I was wondering if you can talk about Wexford and you commented having worked on it many times and having a lot of knowledge. And so when you're presented with it, you were able to act fast. And then you called out 3 variables that ultimately lead you to win: the trust that you had with the other parties; the structure that you presented; and then accommodative capital market. And I recognize stars have to align for any deal to occur and you've said that before. How would you rank those 3 variables as we think about other transactions that will come -- could happen? So how important is the capital market side versus the trust that a seller has and the structure that you're creating? How would you weight those and rank them?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of the biggest factors, as I mentioned in my remarks, Michael, is that do we believe that we're entering at a good risk-adjusted return and that the assets are going to produce reliable growth and income. So that is the #1 factor in all deals, d
componenttext: Well, one of the biggest factors, as I mentioned in my remarks, Michael, is that do we believe that we're entering at a good risk-adjusted return and that the assets are going to produce reliable growth and income. So that is the #1 factor in all deals, definitely. And obviously, our funding costs are critical because we are here to add value for shareholders, and so appropriate capital markets is extremely important. And I would say having a good relationship with Blackstone and the Wexford management team is a helpful, facilitated factor in the transaction as well. And the structure is always, I would say, a helpful factor, but normally, it's not this positive. It's really those cash flows. And here, when we look at Wexford and these are new assets, they're Class A assets, and about 3/4 of the NOI is from tenants who have investment-grade ratings, have billion-plus market caps, have AA rated -- or universities. That, to us, is a really good risk-adjusted return when you're looking at 10-plus year length of lease maturities. And so everything came together, I think, in a really positive way. The fact that we've looked at the deal before, I think really shows our discipline and patience, and that's really how we operate here. And so we're very excited about it and I hope that answers your question.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it does. And I was wondering, how would you debate? There's been some that have sort of compared this to some of the core life science markets, where cap rates are in the 4 to 5s. And then taking it one step further that if Wexford came at a high 6s,
componenttext: No, it does. And I was wondering, how would you debate? There's been some that have sort of compared this to some of the core life science markets, where cap rates are in the 4 to 5s. And then taking it one step further that if Wexford came at a high 6s, it has to be lower quality or there has to have much higher risk involved in that portfolio, because it's commanding a cap rate that is significantly in excess of where stuff in Cambridge or South San Francisco would trade. How do you sort of defend some of that criticism?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say the following. The Wexford business is a very institutional business. It matches incredibly well with the Ventas' business model. And I do think that there is a natural segmentation, frankly, between this part of the business and the Cam
componenttext: Well, I would say the following. The Wexford business is a very institutional business. It matches incredibly well with the Ventas' business model. And I do think that there is a natural segmentation, frankly, between this part of the business and the Cambridge, et cetera, cluster market strategy. I would say to you that the reliability of these cash flows is extremely high, and they will produce this reliable growth and income that Ventas prizes and that our investors prize. But it's a different game in Cambridge, really. And there's excellent players like Alexandria and Blackstone, who will invest in those 4, 5 cap rate markets and deal with the turnover and all of that. But Wexford sits with the Ventas business model, and that's really the key thing. It is a very reliable, consistent growth in income, with institutional tenants and even cross-selling opportunities with medical assets as well. So that, I think, if anything, the deal is just a good one for our shareholders, plain and simple.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just last one for me. Can you talk a little bit about sort of the Ardent pipeline and where you stand now that the managers under EIG and where do they stand in terms of growing the platform if you use the capital source? When should we expect
componenttext: Great. And just last one for me. Can you talk a little bit about sort of the Ardent pipeline and where you stand now that the managers under EIG and where do they stand in terms of growing the platform if you use the capital source? When should we expect additional acquisitions there?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, as you know, we're big believers in the growth opportunity in our hospital business. We're really happy with the Ardent investment and the Ardent management team. It is performing very well. We've said all along that this is a big, long-term, s
componenttext: Yes. Well, as you know, we're big believers in the growth opportunity in our hospital business. We're really happy with the Ardent investment and the Ardent management team. It is performing very well. We've said all along that this is a big, long-term, secular opportunity, and we want to build a great business here. We've also said we're going to be very selective, and we are. We want high quality, with all the characteristics that we've talked about over and over again, and we think we can scale this Ardent business. But it is a business where we will stay selective, and therefore, difficult to predict when transactions will meet the hurdle and we'll have something to announce. But really, we feel optimistic about the opportunities and feel really good about the Ardent investment and, hopefully, more to follow at the appropriate time.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Nick Yulico from UBS.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a few questions on your senior housing operating segment. If I look, your portfolio has been kind of steadily losing occupancy quarter-by-quarter over the last year, which suggest you probably can't hold rate growth high for forever or so. You also
componenttext: I had a few questions on your senior housing operating segment. If I look, your portfolio has been kind of steadily losing occupancy quarter-by-quarter over the last year, which suggest you probably can't hold rate growth high for forever or so. You also cited supply being an issue for 30% of your portfolio. So I guess, I'm wondering, big picture here, how does senior housing growth get better in coming years? It seems like it should be getting worse.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Nick, if I step back big picture, I'll emphasize again the value proposition of senior housing. We are bullish on senior housing, short, medium, long-term, because when you look at the services that seniors get in senior housing communities, economi
componenttext: Well, Nick, if I step back big picture, I'll emphasize again the value proposition of senior housing. We are bullish on senior housing, short, medium, long-term, because when you look at the services that seniors get in senior housing communities, economically to replicate that at home is 2x as expensive, not to mention the social benefits of being part of a community, which are proven to be enhancing and extending life. And therefore, there's a great product offering here where affordability, importantly, affordability, if you look at net worth among seniors, affordability of senior housing is not the gating issue. They can afford comfortably, on average, to enter senior housing. So that, together with, of course, the aging population, the megatrend of longevity as a huge tailwind to this business give me and us confidence in that business. Now, within that, as you already point out, we've been driving a rate strategy in light of that value proposition. We think that's a smart move. That really is very much predicated on the annual rent letter. And that increase we saw this year, which was among the highest we've had, has held nicely and is proving out to be a good strategy. At the same time, we're being sensitive to the occupancy impacts. And this is proving out to be a good formula. One that will be dynamic though. I mean, we'll make sure we're managing well because it is a more complex equation between rate and occupancy. But nonetheless, we like where we are. The strategy is proving out very much in line with where we expect it to be. And then short, medium, long-term, this is a great business.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Bob. I guess just a follow up, is I think you've said that -- you've been saying that your second quarter is one of your toughest comps, and I wasn't sure if that was due to occupancy or otherwise. But if I look at what you had, over
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Bob. I guess just a follow up, is I think you've said that -- you've been saying that your second quarter is one of your toughest comps, and I wasn't sure if that was due to occupancy or otherwise. But if I look at what you had, over 91% occupancy in the third and fourth quarters last year, it seems like you also have some tough comps in the back half of the year. So maybe if you could just explain how we should be thinking about your guidance and what it assumes for, I don't know, I forget if this has been mentioned yet, but occupancy, whether it's sort of declining year-over-year, if that's built into the guidance in the back half of the year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. So looking at the guidance for the year in the back half, what we expect to happen is we narrowed the gap, if you look year-over-year, in terms of occupancy, relative to the first quarter to the second. That said, still lower than last year.
componenttext: Right. Okay. So looking at the guidance for the year in the back half, what we expect to happen is we narrowed the gap, if you look year-over-year, in terms of occupancy, relative to the first quarter to the second. That said, still lower than last year. We hope to continue to narrow that gap. But on a full year basis, occupancy will be below prior year. However, rate, we continue to expect, will be strong and to hold with where we are, and that is really important, in part, to cover costs. And therefore, the paradigm of the P&L is one of a revenue growth, very much in line with expense growth to deliver the guidance we gave for the year. So that's the P&L profile. I think if you look within construction markets, you'll see a different dynamic, where we still see rate growth albeit not as strong, and we do see some occupancy pressure. And so for that 30% of the portfolio, you do see a slightly different P&L. But again, because of the engine room, it's more than offset by the key markets to deliver the overall year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Tyler from Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Tyler from Green Street Advisors.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The triple-net assets, the customary growth, I guess, that I expect from those is more than 2% to 3% range, and you reported 4% in the quarter exclusive of the Kindred fee. Didn't seem like there was a ton of role or any role in the portfolio. And I know
componenttext: The triple-net assets, the customary growth, I guess, that I expect from those is more than 2% to 3% range, and you reported 4% in the quarter exclusive of the Kindred fee. Didn't seem like there was a ton of role or any role in the portfolio. And I know you mentioned escalations, but can you just explain how you got to 4% and maybe why it's running, at least so far this year, above the normalized pace?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll highlight a few things. One is we mentioned the Kindred deal that we did in April, which as part of that, you recall, we reallocated rent to more productive assets. We saw that in the second quarter. That's a same-store benefit. That contribute
componenttext: Sure. I'll highlight a few things. One is we mentioned the Kindred deal that we did in April, which as part of that, you recall, we reallocated rent to more productive assets. We saw that in the second quarter. That's a same-store benefit. That contributes to the 4%. And will continue to do so as that rent again was reallocated to asset that could sustain that, given the strength of those assets. So that's 1 driver. And then second, we have a couple higher escalators. We've talked about Holiday for example, the past, in senior housing business, which we are seeing the benefit of. Again, also expected to continue into the back half when we look at it. So that being place escalators notably with a few significant drivers are really what's underlying that, Kevin.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Holiday rolls off this year, correct?
componenttext: Okay. And Holiday rolls off this year, correct?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last 4-ish percent escalator is in the -- in 2016, yes.
componenttext: Our last 4-ish percent escalator is in the -- in 2016, yes.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then within the triple-net bucket, Ardent is certainly a part of that. And CMS was hospital quality star ratings and just on some quick numbers that I looked at it. Looked like the average star rating for Ardent was kind of in the 3 out of 5 ran
componenttext: Okay. And then within the triple-net bucket, Ardent is certainly a part of that. And CMS was hospital quality star ratings and just on some quick numbers that I looked at it. Looked like the average star rating for Ardent was kind of in the 3 out of 5 range, and I'm just wondering how you think about that number, just in general, the ratings, but then 3 out of 5 going forward, does it change revenue? Does it have any impact on the way people make their decisions? We're early, but I'm just curious on thoughts on that.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I'm so glad you asked that. That did come out this week. And if you eliminate the 20% of hospitals that were not rated, and you look at the percentages, Ardent performed well above average and in fact, in its market, performed better than the c
componenttext: Yes. Well, I'm so glad you asked that. That did come out this week. And if you eliminate the 20% of hospitals that were not rated, and you look at the percentages, Ardent performed well above average and in fact, in its market, performed better than the competition. So we were pleased with the outcomes. I know that the management team there is focused ultimately on certainly having everything 3 and above. And ideally, everything in at least a 4, but that's a rarefied air. So we were happy with Ardent's performance and particularly in its markets that it is outperforming the competition on quality ratings.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the last one I had, Bob, just going back to SHOP for a second. On the other more tertiary markets, the 500 bps of occupancy decline was, I guess, higher than I would have thought. And I'm just wondering, is there anything more than just sup
componenttext: Okay. And then the last one I had, Bob, just going back to SHOP for a second. On the other more tertiary markets, the 500 bps of occupancy decline was, I guess, higher than I would have thought. And I'm just wondering, is there anything more than just supply? Or is it really supply specific? It sounds like you're attributing most of it to the new competition, but is there any operational missteps or anything operator-specific that might be in there as well?

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, because we are very transparent and almost all -- virtually all of our SHOP assets are in same-store, there's a redevelopment asset that is bringing down that number, which is the principal driver. As it goes through significant redevelopment and,
componenttext: Kevin, because we are very transparent and almost all -- virtually all of our SHOP assets are in same-store, there's a redevelopment asset that is bringing down that number, which is the principal driver. As it goes through significant redevelopment and, of course, redevelopment can both suppress as well as, over time, increase same-store performance, so that's what's really happening there.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's just a small pool, Kevin, that really stands out on the page. And we saw the opposite to Debbie's point last year where we had a ramp up in one of the redevelopments that really flattered that segment. So you see ebbs and flows in that bucket sim
componenttext: And it's just a small pool, Kevin, that really stands out on the page. And we saw the opposite to Debbie's point last year where we had a ramp up in one of the redevelopments that really flattered that segment. So you see ebbs and flows in that bucket simply by its size.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a tiny pool. It's a tiny pool.
componenttext: Yes, it's a tiny pool. It's a tiny pool.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So, I guess I was under the impression that most of the redevelopment was on the Atria assets and SHOP. But is more going on beyond that? Is that what you're...
componenttext: Okay. So, I guess I was under the impression that most of the redevelopment was on the Atria assets and SHOP. But is more going on beyond that? Is that what you're...

componenttext: Well, that is an Atria asset in SHOP. It's in Cape Cod, which is considered by the MSA nomenclature to be a tertiary market.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Rich Anderson from Mizuho Securities.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: So is the risk of a SHOP going negative off the table now as you see it today? SHOP NOI growth, same NOI growth?

componenttextpreview: Our guidance would certainly suggest so.
componenttext: Our guidance would certainly suggest so.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: The math of the guidance, Rich, would say it's going to grow in the back half. And certainly, our experience in the first half supports that, again, because of the quality of the high variety markets in their momentum. So that's why we raised the lower end for the full year.

headline: Ventas, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm thinking further out though, disruption in '17, '18. Anything -- I mean, so that's the conversation.
componenttext: I'm thinking further out though, disruption in '17, '18. Anything -- I mean, so that's the conversation.
